I can't close my laptop anymore because it only seems as if it's going to fall apart even more than it already has.  I was wondering how much I'd have to pay to get it fixed, even though I find it unfair that this laptop is basically brand new and it's already falling apart on me.

post_full: I bought this HP notebook in September 2020 from HP online website, along with a 3 year Care Pack which expires in September 2023 A few weeks ago the right hinge started to work loose. It now appears to be broken and the case is starting to split apart.  I reported this to HP technical support and they insist it is damage and are quoting £253 for the repair.  The HP Care Pack is an extension of the warranty which states that "if the product is defective, HP will repair or replace the product or refund the purchase price upon return of the product, at HP's option. I explained that the laptop had not been damaged and that the problem was due to the failure of an internal component - but they still insisted that they view it as damage. I feel strongly that HP are reneging on their responsibilities under their warranty. iIhave since discovered that there have been many thousands of cases where hinges on HP notebooks have failed. It has been demonstrated that this is due to faulty design, and In the US, users are proposing to take a class action lawsuit against HP over this issue. There are also many examples on this forum if you search for "broken hinge".Has anyone had this problem and been able to get it fixed under the warranty?

post_summary: I had brought a hp envy 360 laptop in December 2021. On feb 28th 2022 when I was closing my laptop I heard a cracking sound and when I saw, the left hinge was broken. When I took it for repair, the l...
post_full: I had brought a hp envy 360 laptop in December 2021. On feb 28th 2022 when I was closing my laptop I heard a cracking sound and when I saw, the left hinge was broken. When I took it for repair, the local professional said this is happening with everyone. After a year just after your warranty gets over, the hinge will break. He advised me to take it to the hp care. The person at hp care said, the replacement of the hinge will be around 15000 INR but if I extend the warranty by paying 16000 INR they will do the repair for free. I smell something fishy as the physical damage is not covered by the warranty. Then I called the customer care to clarify and they said the same thing, physical damage is not covered in warranty. Now when I reached home I found the screen is also broken. This may have happened during my travel. Now they are quoting around 40000 INR for replacement of the screen. I had brought the laptop for 72000 INR and have to pay 40000 INR to get the hinge and screen replaced that too just after 14 months. I don't understand what was my fault. I didn't do anything wrong, however became a victim of dirty business model. Being a middle class Indian guy, it was very difficult for me to arrange the money to buy this laptop and now it will take about 6 more months before I could get 40000 INR to get it repaired. I had a emotional attachment with the laptop. Now for 6 months I won't be able to use the laptop which is another problem. I won't recommend the HP laptop to anyone, ever. HP broke my trust

It’s probably cheaper to wait if they come back than a recall.

It is very disheartening as I purchased an HP on the recommendation of a friend in the IT Business of praised their support and products. I looked up the parts on the HP website and it will cost $175.16 for both the upper and lower sections. post_summary: ...ine with no cracks, dents, scratches or missing and broken parts besides the hinge, I am very confused. Unfortunately she cannot explain what exactly the issue is (I understand this is not her d...
post_full: The back right hinge on my HP Envy 13 wore down after having it for under 6 months. I took very good care of my laptop and there were no drops, dents, breaks, or cracks on it. I read on these forums and elsewhere that this is a very common problem (Especially with the Envy), so I contacted HP to see what they could do on Dec 20 and described the laptop's condition to the representative after which he assured me that it was covered by the warranty and I should send it in. I further stressed that because of school I would need it back by Dec 30th and asked if this would be possible. I was reassured TWICE that it would be available by then so I paid for the shipping and sent it in. A couple days later a get an e-mail telling me that my laptop will be returned by at earliest Jan 5. I contacted HP support and they assured me they would have it expedited. Two days later I received an e-mail that it has been expedited to... Jan 5 still. I contact them again, this rep was actually honest and said there was no guarantees that it could come sooner. Slightly frustrating, but I understand and I made arrangements with my school to rent a laptop for that time period. No sweat. Yesterday, I got an email from HP telling me to contact them about the laptop. Ok, good news right? First rep over messenger tells me they can fix it (great!) but all that I owe $612, and he can' t say why. So I have to call customer support and figure out why. To this point I'm ok with HP, I understand the process and I'm fine with slip ups and mistakes, whatever it happens I get it. This rep confirms for me that I owe $612 for the repairs because she says they are beyond the normal wear and tear. Since this is such a common issue with the laptop, and since it still works fine with no cracks, dents, scratches or missing and broken parts besides the hinge, I am very confused. Unfortunately she cannot explain what exactly the issue is (I understand this is not her department, perfectly reasonable), and then attempts to get me to pay the $612. Now I paid $660 for the entire laptop when it was brand new so it is pretty ridiculous that this is basically the entire price of the laptop for a broken hinge. I stress that I need to speak to the repair center and I'm informed that customer service does not have their contact info and that they will call me. I once again stressed my timeline and asked to please hear ASAP. I was assured that they would be in contact with me very soon. I'm still being patient so I say I'm fine with that, but I'm starting to feel a little mistreated and my patience is definitely being tested. I still haven't heard from HP why I am being charged for nearly the entire price of the computer, and to be honest there is no way I am paying for basically a new computer, especially if I can't even know why I'm being charged that amount. I'm running out of time and honestly think I'm headed to the Apple store if I can't get this sorted out, or at least have HP give me the time of day after I've been so patient. I stopped using Apple laptops after 9 years to try HP because I heard good things and I do like the computer, but this situation has left a very bad taste in my mouth. I just wish HP would take a little time and actually realize how ridiculous this is, especially since they're in danger of losing a customer.

post_full: HP ENVY X360 CONVERTIBLE 15M-ED0023DX screen coming apart and popping out. My laptop sits on a desk and never moves. I am very careful as this laptop is my only laptop for my home business. I shut the laptop and the screen popped out and made a cracking/grinding noise. My laptop is under an extended warranty, and I am advised to mail my laptop to HP. However, I will be without a laptop. I conduct my business on my laptop. I cannot afford to lose business. I requested a laptop loaner. I was denied. I asked if there was an HP service center in my area. There is no service center in my area.I am faced with a decision. Do I keep the laptop as is (defective and faulty design), so I do not sacrifice losing business or do I mail my laptop in for repair and purchase a backup laptop to use while mine is being repaired. I should not have to purchase another laptop, but that would be my only option. I have seen an extensive amount of reviews, pictures, and complaints about the HP X360 convertible’s screen hinge coming apart, yet HP continues to sell this product. In this situation, I believe a loaner laptop would be the right thing to do for the customer. However, the situation is this: I purchased a laptop for $1100. The laptop is defective with a design flaw as evidenced by an extensive amount of customer complaints and reviews (it’s a simple google search), I am advised to mail my laptop in with no guarantee of repair time and no loaner laptop. This is more than an inconvenience; this will have a negative impact on my business. This warranty program is not designed with the customer in mind. If it were, then there would be a reasonable loaner program. People need reliability in the products that they spend hard earned money for. I understand laptops/computers have issues. However, HP has been notified of this HP ENVY X360 CONVERTIBLE 15M-ED0023DX screen coming apart and popping out time and time again, but continue to manufacture and sell this same laptop. It isn’t right. The laptop loaner program isn't right.

post_full: Hi, the left hand hinge is broken on my laptop resulting in the touchscreen malfunctioning and potential other issues.  It seems this is a known issue with this product and that it is not, in fact, the hinge but rather the base of the outer case screw receivng point camming out over time so that it loses connection and allows the back left portion of the outer casing to bend, dislocate  and become seriously loose.  Given this is an inherent known design flaw can anybody from HP please comment about repairs?  I note also that since knowing about this HP has changed the hinge design.

post_summary: Hi.  The right hinge of our HP Envy x360 just randomly broke.  This machine was purchased at the end of November 2017, less than 2 years ago.  I am a tech for the small business using this d...
post_full: Hi.The right hinge of our HP Envy x360 just randomly broke.This machine was purchased at the end of November 2017, less than 2 years ago.  I am a tech for the small business using this device.  The two screws popped out and the plastic holding in those screws, and now the screen is separated from one hinge.   The device is now unable to support itself or rotate correctly.  The issue actually occurred a couple months ago, but they have been using the device since without other options.   Looking online this issue seems to be widespread for countless users with similar purchase dates and similar breaking points.  Our company works alongside countless business's and schools and this is just wrong for a higher end product, built on the feature of rotation all the way around to break in such a manner.   The business should not have to pay for such a clearly widespread problem.  It also appears the only way to address this issue is by this means of posting on the forums.  My support calls were unable to get to anyone willing to deal with the issue.  We buy and suggest numerous devices to our clients.  I will not be recommending the envy.  I hope I can get some sort of help with this. Thanks, Alex

post_full: Hello, just a few days ago I noticed that the display bezel is coming apart from the display leaving a gap. Took it upon myself to open the device and investigate the problem. The issue seems to be that the base on which the hinges are fixed onto the display back cover have become brittle and broke into pieces causing the display to wobble when the notebook is open. The hinge itself is pushing onto the display bezel causing it to separate from the display. I have uploaded pictures of the broken fixing points and the display bezel coming off to Imgur since it wouldn't let me attach them to the post. I would like to know if it's possible to have the back cover and the bezel shipped to Germany since the official spare parts website says that they are out of stock.I believe the numbers for the parts are as goes: Back cover: L20313-001Display bezel: L20309-001Thanks in advance!Link to photos: imgur.com/a/2ZwqChG (Would not let me attach them)

post_full: Hello,  I purchased an HP Envy Touchsmart 15 a little over a year ago. The hinge seems to have come unglued fromt the inside. I read that the HP Envy is prone to this, since the hinge is glued in production as opposed to being fastened with a screw. I'm a graduate student, and I'm unable to use my HP for schoolwork due to the faulty hinge. The computer has been handled carefully, and it's never been dropped. This is my first HP. It was great when it was working; however, a laptop that costs nearly a grand and works only for 1 year due to the construction is extremelhy dissapointing.  I'm wondering if anyone else has had this problem and how it was handled by HP. I purchased it through costco, so I should have an extended 2 year warranty on the device.  Thanks in advance,  Alexandria

post_full: The right hinge of my HP Envy x360 laptop has broken off internally. Searching the forum, it appears this is a design flaw in the hinge for the Envy x360 series. I've found several posts with the same problem.https://h30434.www3.hp.com/t5/Notebook-Hardware-and-Upgrade-Questions/Defective-Left-Hinge-HP-Envy-x....https://h30434.www3.hp.com/t5/Notebook-Hardware-and-Upgrade-Questions/Quality-issues-with-Envy-x360-....https://h30434.www3.hp.com/t5/Notebook-Hardware-and-Upgrade-Questions/Broken-Breaking-hinge-on-HP-EN....https://h30434.www3.hp.com/t5/Notebook-Hardware-and-Upgrade-Questions/Defective-Left-Hinge-HP-Envy-x.... However, a few of the above posts imply that HP may be doing something about remediation for those affected by this apparent design flaw.I believe my laptop is out of warranty, which means I have no recourse other than to pay out of pocket for the repair, and I do not want to pay for an obvious design flaw on the laptop. I've been cautious with my laptop, and I do not force the lid close or anything that would cause this damage. Up until this hinge broke, I was very happy with the laptop. I even recommended it as a purchase to several people. I've since rescinded that recommendation because of this design flaw.

post_summary: My case has broken at the left hinge.  It was fixed by HP under warranty, but the fix didn't last, so I decided to fix it myself.  Lots of broken plastic in the area, but got it cleaned u...
post_full:
My case has broken at the left hinge.  It was fixed by HP under warranty, but the fix didn't last, so I decided to fix it myself.  Lots of broken plastic in the area, but got it cleaned up and JB welded all the breaks and added reinforcements.  Seems to be good as I temporarilly attachd the display and it open and closes as it should and the case is holding together.Now the problem:  There are 2 black wires from the display that connect to the motherboard.  They are numbered 1, and 2, and to make sure I got them back where they belong  I marked one with a red sharpie ( I didnt see the numbers on them until after they were disconnected ).  For some reason, ( distractions ) I must have neglected to mark the connector that the red marked lead goes to.  Can someone here tell me which lead goes where?  I don't want to have gone to all this work and wind up blowing something up.  Also, please tell me how the connectors work.  I can't seem to figure out how to put them together.



					
						Solved!
					
					Go to Solution.

post_summary: Hallo,  ich habe am 18.08.17 mein NOtebook NTB HP Envy 15x360 15-bp007ng FHD  i5 nagelneu gekauft. Das Notebook ist um 360 Grad  klappbar mit tablet Funktion. Nach 2 Jahren und 6 Wochen habe ich  fes...
post_full: Hallo,ich habe am 18.08.17 mein NOtebook NTB HP Envy 15x360 15-bp007ng FHDi5 nagelneu gekauft. Das Notebook ist um 360 Gradklappbar mit tablet Funktion. Nach 2 Jahren und 6 Wochen habe ichfestgestellt, dass sich der Deckel des Bildschirms vom Bildschirmlöst, da dort das Plastik gebrochen ist an der rechten unteren Ecke,wo das Scharnier ist. Das bedeutet, dass eine Lücke zwischenBildschirm und Deckel sich auftut und der Laptop nur zugeklappt werdenkann mit dem Risiko, dass die Kabel und Halterung herauskommen.Das Notebook wurde in den 2 Jahren insgesamt ca. 30x geklappt. Nichtöfter, da es nicht transportiert wurde und die Funktion als Tabletsehr selten genutzt wurde. Das Notebook wird generell nur für denPrivatgebrauch am Wochenende für max. 4h genutzt und steht an einemfesten Platz.Wie kann es sein, dass das Material anscheinend so minderwertig ist bzw. die Verarbeitung, dass es selbst dieser geringen Belastung nicht standhält?Können Sie mir bitte mögliche Optionen nennen, was man tun kann nach Ablauf der Garantie? Und zu den anderen Kommentaren, die die extrem schwachen Scharniere bemängeln:Ja, das war von Anfang an der Fall, dass diese extrem schwach waren und sich der Bildschirm bei der kleinsten Berührung selbstständig weiter nach hinten geklappt hat bzw. wenn ein bestimmter Winkel überschritten wurde, er ganz nach unten klappte - und das bei einem nagelneuen Model für über 1000€.Vielen Dank für eine Rückmeldung!

And the bottom right corner of the display is popped out. (Made it easy to remove the broken display) I reinstalled the new lcd display and went to click it in to place and noticed 2 screws are missing from the right hand hinge. Tried to tighten the one screw that was left and it was even touching anything... So I unscrewed one from the left side and saw the bushings that are inserted into the holes of the hinge...gently tried to remove it to maybe rig it so each side had some support.... But no luck... Then I spent 20 minutes searching the web for these bushing replacement and I can't find anything that will work.... How do I fix this part of the laptop which is a load bearing piece due to the screen swiveling as far as it does.......???? When I say bushing, I mean the little plastic and metal pieces that fit inside the hole to make it possible for the tiny screw to screw in.... I thought new hinges should come with them already inside.. nope....just open holes... Help????

post_summary: ...ve lost out on half an years warranty services.      FLASH BACK: DUBAI - Notebook bought on the 3rd of Feb, 13 - High hopes.  SKIP TO PRESENT: INDIA - Broken hinge and warranty lost....
post_full:
I bought HP over Acer, Lenovo and Asus because i believed that the one thing that HP offers each time, is exquisite build quality. However, today I was met with a nasty surprise. The left hinge (one near the power button) has seemingly come undone, as if on its own.  Surprised as I was, I contacted technical support. Surprise Surprise, my warranty information is wrong. Ive lost out on half an years warranty services.  FLASH BACK: DUBAI - Notebook bought on the 3rd of Feb, 13 - High hopes.SKIP TO PRESENT: INDIA - Broken hinge and warranty lost. So I took a deep breath, and opened up the trusty HPSA again, informing the specialist about my "mistaken date of purchase" (note, I am in India at the time). I am informed by the technician that i have to "contact the HP tech assistance in UAE to rectify the issue." STRIKE ONE. So, everyone knows how "good" the waranty services in India are. I remember having an old all in one HP printer. The printer malfunctioned, so we took it to the closest "Authorised" HP service centre. The first day we went, we werent given any "service". The next day we went, they claimed NOTHING under the warranty covers it. They could be right, but oh well, we paid for rectification. So now I'm feeling like its going to be a repeat of the last time. And its funny, since I have found A LOT of people with the same problem. I dont want to rubbish the customer support, BECAUSE I HAVE SEEN THEM HELP OTHER PEOPLE. The sad part is that these people are mostly from the States.  Maybe its not justified, but it always seems like the developing countries get the worst of both worlds. We are the highest consuming population, yet we get the inflated prices (which I know are due to a lot of factors outside the control of the company) and poor service.  I cant believe that there is not a single HP service centre in Mumbai is, well, purely HP, and not a 3rd party "authorised dealer". I guess cant do anything about it and maybe I write this in vain, but if someone is listening (or reading), can I suggest atleast have ONE non third party service centre. It'll help a GREAT deal. I hope someone can help me. Ak 



					
						Solved!
					
					Go to Solution.

My laptop being over a year old is out of warranty, but seeing the same issue pop up again and again for this particular laptop, I can't help but think that HP is in some way responsible for selling a faulty product. Can HP repair my laptop or help in anyway? At the very least I sincerely suggest you consider recalling this model of the HP Envy and revise the construction of the hinges. I did not mistreat my laptop and having spent so much on it, being in this situation is devastating. I hope for the sake of HP and its customers, they consider this issue.

post_full: Hello!I am wondering if there is anything I can do about the broken hinges on my laptop. The laptop is out of warranty, however everything is working fine on it aside from the broken hinges, which have caused the plastic holding up the display screen to crack over time because the screen is not properly supported. The broken hinges occurred with normal use, not from carelessness. On the phone with customer support, they acknowledged that this was a manufacturing issue, but that I was not able to get it repaired because too much time had passed since I purchased the laptop. I have seen other customers talk about the HP design issues that have caused the hinges on their laptops to break.Is there anything I can do? I don't understand how I'm responsible for HP's design issue. I do not have money for a new laptop or a repair. Even though the laptop is older, it would still be in perfect, usable condition if not for the design issue that led to the hinges breaking when they shouldn't have. I would understand if there was other damage that was my own fault, but the hinge design issue is well-documented and customer support representatives also acknowledged that it was a manufacturing issue.Thank you for your help!

post_full:
I'm writing in this thread because I've seemed to have noticed an issue that has come up with my relatively new laptop. I purchased my HP ENVY x360 - 15m-cp0011dx brand new from Best Buy in early to mid-June of last year (2019) and already, the hinge is having issues. Now I've noticed quite sometime earlier that the right hinge on my laptop was a little off and crooked, but nothing seemed wrong with the screen position or opening and closing the lid. But recently, I've realized that now the right hinge is making a small crack or popping noise when open and close the lid. And I've also noticed that when my laptop is shut, the broken hinge is literally causing the laptop screen to be misaligned with the bottom portion of the laptop. I"m very upset because I've managed to upgrade the system's ram and have a lot of personal things and progress stored on this laptop, and now I may have to return it. This really shouldn't be happening to a brand new, quite high-quality laptop that costs around $800. I've taken good care of this laptop and have not dropped it or bumped it into anything, or done anything to cause harm like this to the computer. And obviously, with COVID-19 going around, all Best Buy stores are closed so I can't do anything right now. So my questions are these; Best Buy said I only had a 14-Day window to return this laptop in case anything were to happen to it, which is obviously long gone by now. Will the manufacturer warranty cover this damage? It was not caused by me and obviously came from use, but it shouldn't happen this early to a brand new laptop. Best buy said the manufacturer warranty only covers internal hardware damage that was not caused by the user but rather manufacturer error. And speaking of which, I just checked my laptop's manufacturer warranty status, which is supposed to last for a year. My warranty status "Warranty Removed from Product" because this laptop was apparently "Designated to be returned to HP. Thus, the warranty has been removed from product", and I had no idea about this and was not notified. I'm very upset and infuriated with this issue right now because this HP laptop hasn't been a reliable product, especially for its price, and the warranty seems to be obsolete and no longer reliable as well. How can I rely on the services that HP has to offer and another laptop if I were to purchase from HP again when I can't even rely on a brand new laptop that only lasted for about 6 months? Image of Warranty Status:



					
						Solved!
					
					Go to Solution.

Hi, I have (amongst others) an HP Office jet 6210 printer given to me 12 years ago by my daughters. It has performed magnificent service over the past 12 years, but alas, as seems to be the case with many other owners, both ADF hinges have broken (the hinges supporting the main body you lift when replacing cartridges). I have purchased replacement hinges as I am loathe to throw away a present from my daughters but the left hinge sits lower than the right when screwed in with the Hex 12 screws. This means the left side of the lid now "sits" on the printer body (it was always lower than the right side (and most people in the community appear to comment that the left hinge breaks first). I have checked the broken old hinges with the new ones and they are identical. So, can anyone please help me to keep this prized and trusted jewel working?Thank you in anticipation.

post_summary: ...arranty (1 year manufacturer's + 1 year Costco) and this past Friday (4/30/2021) I went to go open my laptop and the hinge was broken/misaligned. There is a substantial gap between the screen and the keypad a...
post_full: Please help! After saving up my money for over a year, I was finally able to afford (with some help from a promotion being run on Costco) for a HP Envy 360 Laptop in June 2019. I bought the warranty (1 year manufacturer's + 1 year Costco) and this past Friday (4/30/2021) I went to go open my laptop and the hinge was broken/misaligned. There is a substantial gap between the screen and the keypad and I am worried that if I do not fix the laptop, the hinge will snap and my entire laptop will stop working. Similar to other posts I have read, this doesn't sound like a "normal wear and tear" situation, but, rather a manufacturing defect. After saving up for over a year I have been very careful with this laptop and it is disappointing that this malfunction has happened and there is no one I can get into contact to help me resolve the issue. From a quick search with this laptop and hinge in the subject, over 2000 posts came back, this doesn't seem like an isolated incidence.  Picture of my Laptop: Back: The left hinge is misaligned from the rest of the laptop (right side on this picture) Front of the Laptop (Notice how the left hinge is not aligned) -- It is sticking straight up versus being on a tilt like the other hinge  Closer View of the Hinge (From the Front) After googling and trying to get in contact with Costco (this item does not fall under their warranty) and HP (the product is past the warranty) I have been unable to get in contact with anyone at HP to help me with the problem.  Realistically speaking, with the amount of money I paid for this laptop, I was planning on using this laptop for as long as possible. Barely 2 years in and the hinge is broken and I can't even get any live support to help me with the problem.

post_summary: Bought this laptop just short of a year ago for my wife.  Recently discovered the case is broken at the hinges, and the camera has stopped working (no longer listed in device manager).  &n...
post_full: Bought this laptop just short of a year ago for my wife.  Recently discovered the case is broken at the hinges, and the camera has stopped working (no longer listed in device manager). Researched the broken case/hinges and have found it is a common problem with these HP laptops, apparently has been for a lengthy period of time, and that HP doesn't care as they have not responded by altering/strengthening the hinge attachment points on their laptops.  Chalk that up to being a huge corporation, and planned obsolescence is profitable!  Nonetheless, there are a plethora of videos/forum posts about HP laptop broken cases - all the same: the brass inserts have broken out of the thin plastic supports.  With this in mind, I'm wondering if others who've run into the same problems have had problems getting HP to warranty/replace the cases?  How much of a fight am I likely to have on my hands getting HP to fix the case? The other problem is the camera malfunction.  It was showing and disappearing from device manager, alternatively functioning and not functioning.  Finally, it rarely if every is displayed under device manager and is never functional.  Have searched for and reinstalled the latest device driver, and recently reinstalled the OS (win 10); but to no avail.  Haven't been able to find much of anything regarding this camera malfunction.  Any ideas why this is happening?  Broken wiring?  Faulty camera hardware?  Driver/software problem? Thanks for your assistance!

post_full: Hi! I have the hp envy laptop. I use my laptop meticulously. The left hinge just popped open and now the screen at the bottom left is opening. This laptop was not misused or mishandled in any way. As I put my issue into the hp community search bar countless threads popped up of customers who have had the same issue. This issue seems to have already happened on envy laptops snce 2014! My laptop is just 2 years old. I assume my warranty is expired. This really calls into question HP's brand and the quality of their products.   This is clearly a design flaw, a defect,  When I contacted HP they say I should just take it to a local repair place with a price quote of $150 to $300. HP, as a reputable company, should please stand behind their product and take responsibility for a design flaw in an otherwise great laptop! Hope to hear from you soon!Thank you!

post_full: I opened my laptop up to begin my Monday at work, and the right hinge gave out with an awful *CRRRIIICCCK* noise. Now my screen is separated from the lid any time I attempt to open it. Thankfully it did not shatter or compromise the LCD panel when this occurred.Having always taken care of this device (since it is critical for my job as a support specialist while on call,) I am disappointed that the hinge has failed seemingly out of nowhere. I am concerned that if I open the device too often it will tear the screen permanently away from the lid or otherwise destroy it. This seems like a design flaw as I have seen many other similar threads in my research with no good resolution. Naturally, my warranty period expired just a few weeks ago...  While I have a lot of experience repairing electronics, the repair process involves removing the entire LCD panel from the lid and removing easy release tape which I do not have on hand to put it back together. There is also the sinking feeling that this could happen on the other hinge at any time and render the device even more useless. Please advise on my options.

post_summary: ...he left hinge is loose and not quite aligned right. HP said send it back and they would rush the fix. They sent a box and paperwork that does not reflect what I was told. Nothing about the actual p...
post_full: 7 months old HP ENVY X360.... I noticed the left side of my screen casing splitting when I would try to open and close my laptop. This thing is supposed to go all the way around to use as a tablet. I have never even used it that way. Just opened and closed it. Never dropped, Never even took it out of the house. I am a senior so I am gentle with things. Upon closer examination it appears that the left hinge is loose and not quite aligned right. HP said send it back and they would rush the fix. They sent a box and paperwork that does not reflect what I was told. Nothing about the actual problem I was having or the rush and the free pick up I was supposed to get was not included. I was uncomfortable sending it back so I researched online and found that I am not alone with this hinge issue, and some people had been waiting weeks to get theirs back. The hinge issue is a common one because it runs so hot that it melts some flimsy plastic part that eventually melts and causes the hinge to fail. Of people that sent it back under warranty most were accused of dropping it and told it would cost them to fix it. Of the ones who paid for the fix it only lasted 3 months or so. I have had issues with this from the beginning with it freezing up after every update. I have spend countless times with HP assistant fixing it after an update and finally tried to turn off all updates.  It runs hot and frankly I feel I wasted $600 on this thing and need to go buy something decent  If they want to send me a brand new one I will try again, and then wipe this and send it back. I do not want to fix this. It's a bad design and will just happen again. To me this should be a recall.  Is there a way I can get a credit toward upgrading it to a better design? Something more sturdy that is not going to break? And one that will not crash every time windows updates.  Photo of the issue below

post_full: I have had my HP ENVY X360 for about 4 months (bought new). Yesterday when I went to close the screen I heard a cracking popping noise. I opened the laptop back up to find the left hinge broken and a crack in the screen from the hinge attachment area. I contacted support today (10/21/2021) and they told me that if it was just the hinge it would be covered under warranty, but because the screen cracked, it is not. The screen cracked because of the broken hinge. The only way to prevent this issue would have been if I had known the hinge was faulty and never have opened or closed my laptop. This is unreasonable.

The bottom right corner of my computer screen popped open the other day.  Today I tried to open it and the (now apparently broken) hinge crushed through the front glass. Two small screws or rivets fell out and it cannot be open or shut without doing further damage.  Other than that it works great.  Given that I bought it in late 2017, it is out of warranty, but I wanted to post here to see if the admin or community had any advice or suggestions.  It's a great laptop.  I'm really bummed it's broken like this.  I would love to get it fixed with minimal cost. Is this some kind of recall maybe?  ThanksBen

post_summary: ...essage could easily get lost/be ignored in doing so.     The left hinge on my laptop failed over Christmas and resulted in the bottom left of the screen jutting out:           Luckily, the screen a...
post_full: Hi, First off, I would like to apologise for starting a new thread. I've seen quite a few issues around this topic on this forum so could have jumped onto one of them but thought my message could easily get lost/be ignored in doing so. The left hinge on my laptop failed over Christmas and resulted in the bottom left of the screen jutting out: Luckily, the screen and touchscreen are still fine. I got in contact with HP on the 29th of December. I decided to ring them back today as I hadn't heard anything from them. I kind of wish I hadn't as they've quoted me £314.29 () for its repair. They also claimed that it wasn't a manufacturing defect.  To give you some background info: it's in warranty, but as I brought it second-hand, HP tells me that that voids the warranty. I have tried getting in contact with the person I brought it off but had no response.  I guess I've come on here to get people's opinions really. I'm obviously frustrated at what I would consider a relatively new/modern laptop breaking so soon. What has really annoyed me, however, is the cost of repair on top of that. From reading other people's threads on the issue/watching YouTube vids, it seems to be the piece of plastic holding the screws that will have broken. So feel like I'm basically being asked to pay £314.29 to replace a small piece of plastic .  So - should I just shut up, stop moaning and pay the £314.29? (I wish I could afford to). Or, has anyone had any luck getting a repair much cheaper than what I'm being quoted by going down another avenue I'm not sure of?Thanks for your time. Ben

post_full:
Hi pals, I'm just after some advice really. I've had this laptop a while now - about two years. Within a couple of months of owning it, one of the hinges broke. Then after a while, the second one started to go as well. I really should of got it fixed earlier, but I haven't got round to it. The laptop still runs OK, but I've obviously a bit worried about it going kaput in the near future unless I manage to sort out the hinge issue. My questions are really as follows:Does every single HP laptop have different hinges? I'm looking on ebay at the minute for some used replacements and there's so many different options. I would of thought all HP Envy 17 laptops would have the same hinges...am I wrong to assume this? I'll give you an example: there's this one: http://www.ebay.co.uk/itm/HP-Envy-17-1000-Series-17-1050ea-RIGHT-Screen-Bracket-Hinge-FBSP8028010/18... - then there's this one: https://www.ebay.co.uk/itm/HP-Envy-17-J-17-J141NA-LCD-Screen-Support-Hinge-Bracket-6055B0025601-LEFT...I'm basically not sure which hinges I should be buying.Secondly, looking at the pictures, is there anything else I might need replacing? I need a new battery as well, so I'm just trying to work out whether it's worth getting everything fixed on this laptop or just waiting for it to die and get a new one.Thanks for any help/advice you can give.My laptop produce number is F7T68EA#ABU if that's any help.Ben

post_summary: ...t, causing the hinge to break (with just a small amount of force).        The inconvenience of a broken hinge is one thing (the laptop cannot be closed and the screen sags somewhat), but worse is t...
post_full: My friend, who is a retired septuagenarian, has a machine which is reported in system information to be an HP Laptop 15-bs0xx.  She really likes this machine and has had it less that two years. Unfortunately, recently, when being placed on an upholstered footstool, it apparently caught the bottom right edge of the top on some fabric and a small amount of torque was applied to it, causing the hinge to break (with just a small amount of force).  The inconvenience of a broken hinge is one thing (the laptop cannot be closed and the screen sags somewhat), but worse is that this damage seems to have affected the electronics.   Sometimes the image on the screen fads or disappears in parts, and other times information from the computer to the screen is not updated.  Worst of all, the computer is now subject to frequent crashes (random except for the fact that they are far more frequent when it is being moved from place to place) that were never experienced until this mishap. I gather HP has had problems with hinges breaking and has mostly been unable to response satisfactorily to these problems.  However, I think my friend can live with the broken hinge, provided that the issues with the electronics themselves can be addressed. The machine is less than two years old!   And this was reportedly a very small amount of force placed upon it.   Does anyone have any advice on what can be done?  I have open up an HP chromebook before to reseat a wifi card, with positive results, so I do not mind trying to open this one up and hopefully might find that there is just some cable which has become somewhat detached, or something like that.   Otherwise, attempting to get it serviced is probably not worth the cost...

But now when I tape up the casing tight (no more gap when the lid is opened), there's no more connection to mains being made any more.Clearly the repeated action of the broken hinge has affected the power connection. Any simple fixes for this? If I need to take it for repairs, would it be a simple job (not costing hundreds)?Thanks...

post_full: I too have a broken hinge, and perhaps the other one waiting to break. The computer was purchased Dec 2018, so it is just barely out of the warranty period. Obviously this is a known issue to HP. There are so many complaints about this issue, it would seem only right that HP should have these computers fixed free of charge to their customers. We thought we were purchasing a quality brand only to find that at least these parts are so badly designed that they are breaking very quickly. This is not good customer service, or any way to keep customers returning to your products. This will make me question ever buying an HP again, even though I have for many years. The service center listed here is UBreakIFix,  so HP could easily have this fixed at the company's expense and not mine. I already paid for my laptop, and it should certainly not be breaking barely a year later. This has been frustrating, that there is no support for HP products except this. No phone, no email.

post_summary: so August of 2020 I bought this laptop, and have absolutely loved it. today I went to open it and heard a CRUNCH, I looked in the bottom corner and the Screen is bending out next to the hinge, now i...
post_full: so August of 2020 I bought this laptop, and have absolutely loved it. today I went to open it and heard a CRUNCH, I looked in the bottom corner and the Screen is bending out next to the hinge, now it's out of warranty so i figure why not try and see if it is possible to repair. I take it apart and notice that the plastic that the hinge mounts to is just disintegrated. I haven't misused this laptop, it's never been dropped, i even bought a plastic cover for it to prevent the aluminum from getting scuffed. I google hinge problems for this model and low and behold it's a common issue that HP doesn't seem to care to fix or address. Here i sit with a disassembled laptop with a completely busted hinge that i am reluctant to replace since it seems like it'll just likely happen again... Absolute garbage that this happens quite frequently and because it's out of warranty HP wipes their hands of it... they say you must have dropped it or damaged it somehow, or you need to fix your manufacturing process... this is a multigenerational thing.

post_summary: ...mazing that it is still working (somewhat) even though the left hinge is completely broken apart, and it is connected only with the hinge on the right side.  All of the plastic at the bottom of t...
post_full: So, apparently HP has gotten away with this manufacturing defect on the Envy laptop hinge.  This was an expensive computer for me, and it started breaking apart about 2 years ago.  It's amazing that it is still working (somewhat) even though the left hinge is completely broken apart, and it is connected only with the hinge on the right side.  All of the plastic at the bottom of the screen is broken off, except about 4 inches around the right hinge. It has never been dropped or mistreated in any way.  I stopped at a local computer shop a year ago to inquire about getting it repaired.  As soon as I described the problem, I was told this was a known defect on those HP models, that people had already brought some of them in for repair, but they were not able to fix it.  I've purchased many HP products over the years, including laptops, desktops, and printers, not just for personal use, but for small business use.  Never again.  Clearly, quality control is not an important issue for HP.

post_summary: Hello,    I have an HP Envy x360 Convertible that is just under 2 years old and sustained a broken left hinge today. I was closing it gently and normally when there was a sound of crunched plastic a...
post_full: Hello,I have an HP Envy x360 Convertible that is just under 2 years old and sustained a broken left hinge today. I was closing it gently and normally when there was a sound of crunched plastic and the hinge froze up, causing the top cover to push outward because it had become unattached from the hinge. One of the metal rivets and some small pieces of plastic where the rivet had been mounted to the lid fell out of the narrow gap between the screen and lid. I gently realigned the lid & screen with the hinge and have kept it open since this happened.I use this laptop only for personal use about 2 times a day and it has been extremely well-taken care of. I have only used the convertible rotation feature less than 10 times since I purchased it and given that this would be a very gently used personal laptop, I never would have felt that an extended warranty would be necessary for what I believed to be a quality product from this company.I am extremely unhappy about this happening considering it is the first and only laptop I have ever owned and I have had numerous HP desktops over the years with no issues. It appears that this is a common and known issue with these HP hinges over many years and yet the problem persists.I have been a dedicated HP customer for a long time and I hope that HP will help repair this issue, knowing that it has been a long-standing design problem. Thank you.

One of the hinges is loose and pops out of place every time I open the laptop, which is quite concerning and means that I have had to try use other devices to do work for fear of this leading to a cable snapping or becoming damaged. It seems to be quite a common issue with HP Envys and is disappointing as I otherwise really like my laptop, but this is dissuading me from HPs a bit as I have taken measures to be careful with the laptop. I'm currently looking into prices for local repair services, but any help or advice would be greatly appreciated.

I have this hinge problem again and again. This problem is not just mine. There are plenty of questions in the support forum. 
 
After just over 2years of my purchase of HP ENVY TS 15 Notebook PC, I am started having this problem. (Such a time.  just after warranty. Of course). From top right hinge which is just next to charging point lost crew suddenly and began to come loose every time I open and close the laptop and it is getting worse. Then it wasn't charging. I was using my laptop very carefully and never dropped it. Even though a person who fixed my laptop must have seen it how well I kept it. 
 
Now I am thinking that this problem might be some manufactural issue. Hence, I really want to send back to have some quality inspection. 
 
PLEASE HP CONSIDER MY ISSUE AND TAKE SOME ACTION.

post_full: I noticed that many people are reporting this broken hinge issue, and it seems to be on more than just my model.  All of the other reports show resolved with no actual resolution.   Does HP plan to fix this issue or is there a recall of some sort? It seems to be a widely known defect at this point.  There are some YouTube videos showing a fix, but it does require completely disassembling the laptop and gluing the broken hinge into place.  Not a very good fix and not recommended unless you are very expert on the hardware.  Of course this would also violate any warranty, so I am not recommending it, just mentioning the fix is not an easy one and probably costly as lots of labor is involved in taking the laptop apart.   So HP, is there a solution coming???

post_tags: ["HP ENVY x360 Convertible Laptop PC 13m-bd1000 (460Q3AV)", "Microsoft Windows 11"]
post_full: I have been using the HP Envy x360 convertible laptop for about 6 months and this is the fist issue I have had with it. Recently after using the laptop in tablet mode, I heard a loud crunch after rotating the screen back to the closed position. Upon opening up the laptop again, it was apparent that the right hinge popped out of place and did not rotate with the screen, which caused the the bottom right portion of the screen to crack due to it not closing properly. I was extremely confused what caused the damage because I was using the device exactly as intended. After a bit of research, it was clear that I am not alone and this seems to be a reoccurring issue with this model. I contacted customer support and was told that the damages were not covered under warranty and I would have to pay $400 (half of the original price) to get it repaired. It is absurd to me that this model is advertised to allow 360 degree rotation, but doing so will break the laptop after 6 months of usage. It is a complete scam to want $400 to repair a known defect of your product. Now the hinge is broken, a portion of the screen is cracked, and the laptop is unable to be folded back into tablet mode. I really need this laptop and do not have the funds to get it repaired, is there any other course of action I can take to get my laptop fixed?

Please let me know on what steps I could do to fix this with the quarantine in place, I am a student and this is my only means of getting my work done. Thank you.

post_full: I have a HP Envy laptop, roughly 15 months old and under warranty: as I opened the lid a few weeks ago there was a loud cracking noise from the left hinge so I closed it again. As I closed it some small bits fell out of the hinge area and a metal plate kind of popped out leaving the screen hanging off on one side. Naturally I contacted HP to have it fixed as it's under warranty but I've spent the last two weeks in protracted discussion as HP have accused me of "clearly" using "force or misuse" to cause this. Opening and closing a laptop lid isn't exactly a difficult skill and I seem to have managed pretty well over the last 20 years in not damaging any of the laptops I've used so I am completely bemused as to why HP think I am responsible for the damage.Further to this, I've Googled "HP laptop broken hinge" and there are countless cases of EXACTLY the same thing having happened to other people with exactly the same response from HP: not our problem!!What is the point of having a warranty if HP can simply absolve themselves from responsibility by saying "you broke it"?!HP quoted me £315 to fix it; they then sent it back to me with a BROKEN SCREEN which it didn't have before (I have before and after photos)!! They have now stopped responding to my emails... Any ideas how this might be resolved?

And according to HP Support Assistant, there aren't any HP service stores in Oahu that handle consumer notebooks, only commercial ones! Every time I try to find HP support on their website to try and contact them about this issue, it reroutes me to looking up HP service stores near me...but there aren't any, since there are none in Oahu. So I'm a bit stuck on how to proceed!

post_summary: I have an almost  two year old HP Envy 360 laptop whose left hinge just broke. When the hinge broke it popped the screen up and now the screen is not working correctly. I've read that this is q...
post_full: I have an almost  two year old HP Envy 360 laptop whose left hinge just broke. When the hinge broke it popped the screen up and now the screen is not working correctly. I've read that this is quite a common problem with HP laptops. I can't believe that my $900 laptop has become unusable due to a poorly installed mechanical part. The laptop has never been dropped or mistreated.This is so unfortunate because it has been an awesome laptop that has always worked wonderfully. It seems as though HP will not acknowledge their poor engineering and craftmanship. There really is no excuse for a laptop to become nonfunctional because the manufacturer can't estimate the adequate hinge size, material, and installation to ensure that their product can be opened. This is really disheartening. I have used HP computers for nearly 20 years. Based on all the other posts it seems as though I will need to purchase a new laptop. Couldn't have happened at a worse time. I am in the middle of preparing my 3rd grade distant learning curriculum that needs to be taught due to Covid-19.

post_summary: While trying to close my HP Envy x360, the plastic piece holding the screws in place on the right hinge fell out (i.e. disintegrated from poor quality) and cracked  the screen. The laptop s...
post_full: While trying to close my HP Envy x360, the plastic piece holding the screws in place on the right hinge fell out (i.e. disintegrated from poor quality) and cracked the screen. The laptop screen cannot be closed at all now.  The laptop has not been dropped or misused at all. It is astounding to me that this problem has been known and reported since at least 2015. HP literally has a video on their YouTube channel to show how to replace hinge panels. This is clearly a serious design flaw that needs to be addressed by HP, and they need to do something to restore trust in the quality of their products. Why has there not been a recall on these products yet? I am extremely angry that customers are expected to pay out of pocket for repairs when this is clearly a manufacturer defect. Had I known this was an issue, I would have never purchased an HP laptop.

post_full: Unfortunately, over the weekend, the hinge of the screen on the lower right side of the laptop has loosened or an opening has appeared there so that the laptop can no longer be closed because the opening keeps expandingUntil now I have used my laptop very carefully and with an additional laptop bag to ensure that there is no damage. The brand HP, which is known worldwide and has very Qualitative products was one of the reasons why I decided to buy a laptop from this brand. There were a lot of laptops for a better price but for me, it was important to pay for a laptop of good quality.  Until now I was very satisfied with that product.Unfortunately, the opening of the frame and screen that occurred over the weekend, disappointed me and made me question how it comes to his problem, without any outside influence. In addition, I would also like to mention that I very rarely used the touch and screen rotation. I would not like to imagine what would have happened if I had used this more often. Yesterday I talked with the HP Hotline in Germany and they wanted to send pictures of the broken hinge and pictures of the screen. I sent the pictures through email and today the HP worker told me that there is nothing that the warranty could cover.They send me an offer to repair that for a price of 461,90 €. When I heard this price I was very shocked because, in my opinion, it is an exorbitant price because the price for new laptops is the same. I am a student in Germany and I am really very disappointed because during the pandemic situation and I have to write exams online and I have to write my thesis. I am lost. I cannot afford to pay the price they are asking for to repair the laptop although it is not even my fault and is clearly a manufacturing issue. I went on to do a little bit of research and sure enough, there were many, many other complaints of their HP Envy laptop’s hinge breaking through normal use. I am extremely upset with this issue.I thank you in advance and would be very happy to receive positive feedback from you. Here are a few of the other complaints: 1. https://h30434.www3.hp.com/t5/Notebook-Video-Display-and-Touch/HP-Envy-Left-Hinge-Broken/m-p/6979085...2. https://h30434.www3.hp.com/t5/Notebook-Hardware-and-Upgrade-Questions/HP-Envy-Hinge-Popped-Open/m-p/...3. https://h30434.www3.hp.com/t5/Notebook-Hardware-and-Upgrade-Questions/HP-ENVY-x360-15T-BP000-HINGE-I...4. https://h30434.www3.hp.com/t5/Notebook-Hardware-and-Upgrade-Questions/Defective-Left-Hinge-HP-Envy-x...5. https://h30434.www3.hp.com/t5/Notebook-Hardware-and-Upgrade-Questions/Defective-left-hinge-HP-ENVY-x... My laptop hinge:

I own 6 HP laptops and have owned 3 others in the past, now all the sudden this, all I can say is thanks!!! How unfortunate, if someone could help id sure appreciate anything I can get.
 
Randy Carlisle

I have read all of the problems other people are having getting the same problem resolved expediently and satisfactorily. I need someone to contact me asap, and I will not be put on hold forever just to be told that they need to transfer me to someone else, and that person does the same thing, and on and on. At the very least this is very poor customer support and service. People buy your computers because they're supposed to be reliable and not have an issue that is clearly caused by poorly designed and/or cheap parts. These computers are not cheap, and we expect not only sturdily built laptops, but ones that will last for a few years at the least without parts breaking that you obviously refuse to admit are defective to begin with, and then refusing to fix what is obviously of your own doing by using poorly designed and/or cheap parts. As a customer of yours, I expect my problem to be taken care of expediently and to my satisfaction. I do believe that there is power in numbers, and there are enough complaints for this apparently very large group to take other action on our behalf if this continual problem is not taken care of without us having to pay ridiculous sums of money to have you fix your problem, and without having to jump through hoops to try to speak with someone who can remedy this problem. I would think that as many complaints as you've had, you would have dedicated personnel to take care of this obviously very large problem. I expect to hear from someone who can take care of this for me in a timely manner. Regards

I have never dropped or done anything to it physically. I take very good care of it. I feel HP should stand behind their product, and fix or replace this for me. Just over one year of owning and using just on a daily average basis, with no harm to it, it is just unacceptable. I know the one year warranty ran out  as soon as I realized the problem was just going to get worse.I paid around £1250 for this and expected it to last for a long time clearly it is a defect in quality, it is like the hinge has seized up. I would like a response from HP as clearly the quality of the external casing is not as good as the internal elements. My son is going to Uni soon and now has no laptop unless I buy another. I don't feel I should have to after spending so much.

post_summary: ...o-9, 27th Cross, 8th B Main  4th Block, Jayanagar, Bangalore -560011       After 2 weeks on 27th May 2020, I have received a quotation from the service center saying "the hinges are broken and w...
post_full: I had purchased a HP laptop on 23rd July 2018 from Reliance Digital Bangalore. Laptop Description : HP Gaming Pavilion - 15-xx0140xxCost : Rs 73,053/- After one and half year of purchase.  From the last week of March 2020, I was  facing the problem during opening and closing of the laptop ( breaking sound with small pieces of plastic material coming out ).    Then, On 13th May 2020 I gave my laptop in the service center as recommended by HP support, TVS Electronics Ltd.(HP Authorized Service Partner)F-2, No-9, 27th Cross, 8th B Main4th Block, Jayanagar, Bangalore -560011 After 2 weeks on 27th May 2020, I have received a quotation from the service center saying "the hinges are broken and we need to replace hinges and LCD back cover which cost Rs 12,272 /- ". And they are giving a warranty of only 90 days from the date of replacement. First I thought only I have this problem. After a search many have the same problem with this type of laptop.  https://youtu.be/79Nb-e3IIS4 One person got the same problem and replaced it and after few months he got same problem again. We give such a huge amount (Rs 73,053) for the laptop thinking about the good quality, software and the good brand. And later without our fault, if we continue to have such a problem, how can we spend Rs 12,272/- for the replacement every time.  So, I would request you to give me a reason why the problem occurs and give me an solution.

As a result the screen is no longer able to stay up under it's own weight and I am very concerned that this will lead to further damage to the laptop. Through searching on forums including this one, it appears this is a common issue and a simple search on the internet will show. What is the suggested response to this ? Since this is clearly NOT because of my mis-handling of the laptop, as I have not had anything happened like this to me before having used laptops for over 25 years. Other than this design flaw, i dont have any other issue with the laptop and works perfectly. Is there something that HP can do to rectify this ? ThanksChi

I have never dropped my laptop at least once nor do I aggressively lift the screen. My warranty has already expired and I don't know what to do. post_summary: I've been researching and found some many related issues the hinge and screen coming apart. This seems that HP has a device design flaw which causes the hinges to become weak and push the screen o...
post_full: I've been researching and found some many related issues the hinge and screen coming apart. This seems that HP has a device design flaw which causes the hinges to become weak and push the screen out and in my case it cracked (which is what happened to me). This laptop has never been dropped or mishandled. It literally happened when I opened my laptop from the closed position.  Which is ridiculous that I have to keep my laptop open at all times now because it continues to destroy the hinges/screen even more if I attempt to close it. This is now a complete disaster since I work from home  needing to use my laptop and  can't use it  properly due to the touchscreen is constantly doing its own thing. I am beyond livid that I have seen people with the SAME EXACT ISSUE. Why isn't HP recalling or bringing any light to this manufacturing problem?  I refuse to pay for HP to replace this at a cost to me. I have had this laptop for 2 years and of course its out of warranty. I would like someone to contact me to resolve this issue and I would request that  HP picks up the cost for the issue or replaces with a new HP laptop that is functional. I don't have money to spend on a new laptop when this  is obviously an HP manufacturing problem and not a consumer issue (since so many people have the same problem). I have taken nothing but great care for my WORK laptop.  If HP does not work with me on fixing this issue I will be contacting an attorney and open a class action lawsuit due to the lack of design functionally  which creates an issue where the hinges are now pushing the screen out. This isn't just a me issue, several hundred people have complained. I was also never made aware that this design when I purchased it was having issue with the charger getting too hot and causing fires. This also opens up an issue since right where the charger goes is right where the issue of the screen pushed out.  Please contact me in resolving this issue or I will proceed in filing the lawsuit. This item should be recalled and people should be refunded their money. This is a very dangerous issue to have.

Owing to numerous repairs over the year, the intenral plastic mount for the right hinge of my HP Envy 15 J163ei laptop screen has broken. The screws can no longer hold the right hinge in place and thus the right portion of my LCD has become damaged from the excess freedom of movment. post_full: I have owned two different type of laptops from HP that have both experienced the same issue. I an now highly frustrated with the lack of accountability on HPs part. Years ago I purchased an HP Envy Touchsmart 17in notebook. I owned it for only a little over two years before I noticed the back hinges started breaking and the backing of the laptop was coming off as well. There were also loose parts inside as it rattles when you move it around. I did tend to open and close it a lot so i did not think too much about it and it had a fairly large screen. So with it being out of warranty, I decided the get a new laptop and did not do really any research to realize that this is a reoccurring issue. I then bought another HP Laptop model 17 by-1022ci. Again about 6 months after the two year warranty is up this laptops back hinges have begun to separate from the back as well. With this laptop I do not close it or open very often at all and I mostly only use it to watch TV shows or Netflix. This time I decided to call HP and see if there was anything that could be done. However the only option that the lady gave when I called was that I could send it in for repair for $325. I really annoyed at the lack of customer service for a loyal customer who has bought two laptops at full price and and has experienced the SAME exact issue on two different type of laptops.  Has anyone else had the same issue of the back hinges breaking and causing separating? Because it cant just be a fluke that the two laptops that i have owned by HP have the same issue.

post_full:
Dear HP Customer Support / HP Community.  I have a January 2020 Manufactured HP ENVY x360 PC purchased form Computer Micro Centers (Yonkers NY).  The warranty period is over - that's another story for later...  I now have the right Hinge Broken problem that many have setforth here Plus the Monitor screen is Detaching from the PC as I attempt to close it.  I'm not trying to Flip it into Notepad mode, that would probably finish it entirely.  Whatta Piece of ***bleep*** !!!  I purchased this particular PC in a scramble in the waning moments having to have a Laptop at Home for working at Home.  Purchased in on March 17, 2020.  It has NEVER been used in Note pad mode, never been dropped or other wise abused in any manner....  
Moreover, per my above reference, after purchasing the PC form a quality Computer Store (MIcro Computer Centers), in Yonkers NY , I called HP to register it.  The rep told me that 1 year Warranty takes affect form the date of Manufacture , NOT the date of Purchase.  I pretested profusely, to no avail...."That's The HP policy"  as I was told. I was incredulous at the statement; when you buy new ANYTHING - cars, appliances, etc., and file the Warranty, it is ALWAYS form the date of Purchase?  It's no matter because even if I had the HP warranty it expired in March 2021.  So now I am victim of Functional Obsolesce.  I have owned with this PC , 4 HP PC products, and except for poor;y designed and functioning cooling fans on the Pavillon models, never had a problem close to this.  I WON"T BUY HP AGAIN !!!  It will cost me half , if not more to fix this    thing, NO Way.  HP, Please make Good here , keep your customers .  Aldo M.

post_full: Recently the screen started popping out of my laptop upon opening and closing it. Upon a closer inspection it turned out that the screw holes that keep the hinge in place broke within the laptop. To my dismay it turns out HP decided that a thin plastic screw hole would be be enough to hold a metal hinge and screw for years to come. The hardware inside is fine, everything is working however everytiime I open and close it I can hear the hinge snap and pop rubbing against the hardware inside. While it may work now im concerned that this can lead to probelms with the screen or hardware later on down the line.  My question is that since this is not a physical defect rather a poor choice of materials by HP is the anyway I could get them to fix it? I've tried getting in contact with someone for a solid 30 minutes now however it seems that they now want you to pay for customer service if your computer is out of warranty. Something that had I have known would have definitely not brought an HP (honestly I'm still baffled how HP thinks this is customer friendly). I have also tried seeing if there was anyway to just purchase the shell of the laptop and move my hardware over as ive said the hardware inside is fine its the shell and the hinges that are causing an issue. However I cant seem to find anything on it.

The left hinge of my HP Envy x360 laptop broke, and shortly after it it did the touch screen shattered.  Searching the forum it appears to me that this is a design flaw in the hinge for the Envy x360 series.  I've found several posts with the exact same problem.https://h30434.www3.hp.com/t5/Notebook-Hardware-and-Upgrade-Questions/Defective-Left-Hinge-HP-Envy-x...https://h30434.www3.hp.com/t5/Notebook-Hardware-and-Upgrade-Questions/Quality-issues-with-Envy-x360-...https://h30434.www3.hp.com/t5/Notebook-Hardware-and-Upgrade-Questions/Broken-Breaking-hinge-on-HP-EN...https://h30434.www3.hp.com/t5/Notebook-Hardware-and-Upgrade-Questions/Defective-Left-Hinge-HP-Envy-x...However a few of the above posts imply that HP may be doing something about remediation for those affected by this apparent design flaw. I believe my laptop is out of warranty which probably means I have no recourse other than to pay out of pocket for the repair.  However the parts aren't even listed as available on the HP Parts store.  I'm leery of purchasing OEM parts from a 3rd party vendor. Up until this hinge broke I was very happy with the laptop. I even recommended it as a purchase to several people. I've since gone back and rescinded that recommendation because of this design flaw.  Unfortunately one of the people I referred did buy the same model.  I've notified them of this problem.

post_full: I bought an HP Notebook - 17-by1061st in April of 2020.  Almost exactly a year later, the hinge broke and black pieces of plastic were spitting out of the back.  The keyboard up near the power jack was cracking so I taped it with gorilla tape.  I discovered the laptop was not under warranty even though I was invited to extend my warranty through a popup invite on my computer.  HP even took my $59.99 or whatever it was for the extended warranty but then told me I didn't have an extended warranty when I complained that my laptop broke after a year.  Since then I have been using my laptop pretty much as a desktop, left open and never closed, on a desk, so it does not become completely unusable.  (Also, it is only with great effort that my laptop screen can be closed so I have stopped doing this at all.)  My computer works but ... it is broken and I have finally decided that I need to get it fixed, even if it costs me hundreds of dollars.  I have learned online that the cheap and defective hinge issue was known to be a problem as many as five years ago but was not fixed by HP.  This has resulted in a class action suit against the company in at least one state, Florida.   My question is:  how do I get my hardware fixed/replaced and how much will it cost me?  And my secondary question is:  is there any point in trying to convince HP to fix or replace my laptop with no charge given that they KNEW they had defective parts, i.e., the cheap hinge?   Thanks.

tear up once the warranty is expired.  They will stop supporting any computer after 3 to 4 years of use and  it just falls apart.  They are built that way so these greedy people can make more money. person but I think it is time to twitch over to APPLE.  There computers are made to last.  It might be a bit expensive but at least they are well build and will not fall apart and they continue to support their products for many years past what HP consider to be disposable and they stop supporting it.  It is sad that American Computers are just that, made to tear up and thrown to the dump after a 3 years of use.   I will never buy another HP and I am going on my Social Media Platform to tell all my 5000 people to share t photo of the damage on my computer due to a hinge breaking my screen. post_summary: Hi ive got an hp 17inch laptop and the left hinge has come away from the screen the laptop is 15 months old so out of warranty . Could anyone one tell me if this is a common issue and would hp s...
post_full: Hi ive got an hp 17inch laptop and the left hinge has come away from the screen the laptop is 15 months old so out of warranty . Could anyone one tell me if this is a common issue and would hp still fix this issue outside of warranty

HP Pavilion x360 - 14-cd0050tuMy wife uses this laptop daily on a desk and had never used the screen rotation feature until yesterday when she opened the display to tablet mode. When fully opened to tablet mode there was an immediate small cracking noise from the display, just above the right hand facing hinge. When the screen was returned to normal laptop position, the display screen protruded and cracked just above the right hand facing hinge. Two screws and pieces of plastic fell out as well. Looking at the screws it was clear the bushels the screws screw into, had broken the plastic on the display back cover. The screws were still screwed firmly into the bushels but the plastic around the bushels had given way (see photo of the 2 screws). This is a common design fault of not just this model but several HP models in the past. I am a retired HPE and spent several years repairing HP laptops under warranty and HP authorization. This damage has been caused by a component failure and not user induced damage. The laptop is outside the one year standard warranty but considering that such a major component has failed within 2 years of purchase, through no fault of the eu and there are dozens of similar posts on this forum, HP should cover this repair. Examples follow.https://h30434.www3.hp.com/t5/Notebook-Hardware-and-Upgrade-Questions/HP-Envy-X360-Hinge-broken/td-p...https://h30434.www3.hp.com/t5/Notebook-Hardware-and-Upgrade-Questions/Hinge-and-Screen-falling-Apart...https://h30434.www3.hp.com/t5/Notebook-Hardware-and-Upgrade-Questions/Broken-Hinge-envy-laptop/td-p/...https://h30434.www3.hp.com/t5/Notebook-Video-Display-and-Touch/ENVY-X360-Screen-cracks-for-no-reason...My wife really loves this laptop and would like it repaired at HP expense please.Considering parts for the display are not available individually and a full display would be required to fix the issue, this should not become an issue for the eu. The full display unit would be highly expensive and is not available from HP Parts store either.

post_full: HP Envy Touchsmart 17, model: m7-j120dx, product: e8a11ua#aba. My friend, who is wheelchair bound, asked me to check out his laptop because the hinge was loose.  Upon examining it I see that the hinge appears to be loose and seperating the back and front so that there is a substancial gap. There are loose parts inside as it rattles when you move it around. When his laptop started giving him trouble from this issue, he set it aside and went out and bought a new HP Touchsart 17 at full retail price and started using that. Now his newer Touchsmart 17 is doing the exact same thing. He told me that his current laptop is still covered under a Geek Squad warranty but the warranty on his old one has expired since he put it in the closet and did nothing with it.Looking online about this issue I see thousands of customers having identical issues. I am thinking this is a material defect issue if there are this many loose or broken hinges/backplates.My friend is a trusting individual who doesn't want to point out a problem. PURCHASED TWO OF THESE AT FULL RETAIL PRICE!!! I told him he should get his current laptop to Geek Squad ASAP because they will repair it for him. My question is: Is there a recall on these or is HP standing behind this issue in any way? I really don't think he should just accept that his laptops fall apart and he goes and buys a new one.

post_summary: My new Spectre 13t-aw100 CTO (custom build with OLED screen) has slow wifi: my other devices get 10Mbs on my home network, but the Spectre gets only 1Mbs.     I think the issue may be related to...
post_full:
My new Spectre 13t-aw100 CTO (custom build with OLED screen) has slow wifi: my other devices get 10Mbs on my home network, but the Spectre gets only 1Mbs. I think the issue may be related to Intel's wifi driver. The driver generates the error message "Windows cannot initialize the device driver for this hardware. (Code 37) The request is not supported" when booted in Safe Mode with Networking. Detailed instructions are below. I don't know if the error message is normal, or if it is indicative of a hardware or software failure, but I suspect it is a software failure in the driver. If your machine does not already have the latest 10/6/2019 version 21.50.1.1 of the Intel driver, there are instructions for installing it on the "Spectre X360 AX201" thread. That thread also has several solutions for slow wifi problems that have worked for other users. However, the solutions did not work for my machine so I have posted this information on this new thread. I worked around the problem by using an external USB Wifi adapter (TPLINK, under $20 at Office Depot). Hopefully, an Intel driver update will fix the problem.More detailed instructions for reproducing the error message: 1) Make sure that you are displaying your desktop on "PC Screen Only".2) Shut down.3) Disconnect all external devices and cables.4) Press the Power button.5) Immediately start tapping the ESC key until you see "ESC...Pause Startup" in the lower left corner of the screen.6) Press F11 for "System Recovery".7) Select "Troubleshoot" (use the TAB and ENTER keys, or the touchpad). Select "Advanced Options".9) Select "Start Settings" (not "Startup Repair").10) Select "Restart".11) Your screen will go blank for a few seconds.12) Select "Enable Safe Mode with Networking" using F5 or 5.13) Your computer will reboot into "Safe Mode with Networking".14) Press WINDOWS+S (the Windows icon key and the S key).15) The search menu should appear.16) Type "device manager" and hit the ENTER key.17) The Device Manager dialog box should appear.18) Expand the "Network Adapters" category, if it is not already expanded.19) Open the properties box for the "Intel(R) Wi-Fi 6 AX201 160MHz" (double click or click and press ENTER).20) On the "General" tab under "Device Status" my machine displays the error message:"Windows cannot initialize the device driver for this hardware. (Code 37) The request is not supported".21) On the "Driver" tab, it lists the build date as 10/6/2019, and the version as 21.50.1.1.22) Shut down.23) Reconnect any external devices or cables.24) Press the Power button to power back up normally.



					
						Solved!
					
					Go to Solution.

post_full:
I have a HP ENVY  Product: E1P14AV Model: 17t-j100.  The left hinge was broken and the fan locked up so I took it apart and found dozens of little pieces of plastic and loose gromets inside the machine.  A gromet was lodged in the fan causing the fan problem.  The left hinge was broken loose and was so hard to operate that it is no wonder it broke loose.  To adjust the hinge I had to remove the touchscreen.  After adjusting the hinge, I cleaned out all the plastic,  secured the hinge and put everything back together. It all works well except for the touchscreen.  The computer does not seem to recognize that there is a touchscreen. In settings I get the message that "no pen or touch input is available for this display. " It worked fine prior to my working on the system.  Please advise what I should do to resolve this issue!  Thanks for any help!!!
