post_full: I grabbed an envy 360 in late November, 16 cores and 64 gb of RAM. I have 3 desktops, am M1 air and an iPad Pro, so it doesn’t get a lot of use. Today I picked it up and sat down on the couch and started to fold it over into tablet form. Never had any issue doing it before. This time, the hinge, casing and screen on one side just starts to separate like it’s just dissolving in front of me. I know y could not believe it. It was almost unreal. A tiny bit of plastic falls out, then a screw, and out of nowhere this thing is toast. I figured this has got to be some crazy random rare event. Certainly not mentioned in the reviews I read. But then I start looking around and it’s bad news on top of bad. Seems super common, worse, seems HP is not interested in taking responsibility for it. is that still the state of the world? Did I just rent this thing for 6 months at $1600? Or does something more sensible go on these days? I was just warming up to HP  too - seems like I may have messed up - the common, crummy, silly pc laptop hardware situation chased me over to Macs for over a decade. Hard to believe I jumped back over for this.

The right hinge has detached from the plate that it screws into behind the screen. The plastic plate has broken and the threads from which the screws on the hinge should go into are stripped. There are places to buy the hinge, but I really need the part number for the plastic plate that the hinge screws into.

Hi. We got an HP Envy x360 13" via the online shop. It was delivered July 29, 2020, which means it still is under warranty. We got it while in the US. We're here now in the Philippines where the unit is being used by my daughter for her online classes. It has never left the house since we got here, it has never been taken outside as all schools here are only doing online classes because of the Covid19 situation. The hinge on the right side broke. We brought it to the HP Service Center where they told us they'd inspect it and determine what parts need to be replaced. They also told us that  if parts needed aren't available locally then they'd source outside the country. Now, we got a message from them saying that they can't repair the unit as the part needed for the unit isn't supported here and that it needs to be returned to the country of  origin, and that we can get it from them now. Is this what  HP service is? We're left to our own resources to have this unit fixed. Checking the community forum, it appears that this issue with Envy x360 hinge is widespread. I'm hoping HP can solve our problem.

post_full: We buy a new laptop about every 2 years. I run an in-home business and I find that computers just start to have issues after that amount of time. My 11-year-old son bought one for himself a year ago after saving money for years and I don't think his made it 6 months before the hinges broke. Now that I am looking into fixing that my own laptop's hinges are giving out! There is no easy fix to this if you notice there is a hinge issue it is already too late to just replace the hinges. I opened my son's and here is the list of items I had to put on order this morning.1. LCD Hinges $18.002. bottom cover $41.99 (due to broken screw mounts)3. backplate cover $39.00 (due to broken screw mounts)4. palm rest case $50.00 (due to broken screw mounts)basically everything on the outside of the computer needs to be replaced and then I have to switch the internal over to the new case. So those of you that are saying there is no fix to this. Yes, there is a fix you just need to look for your computer model number and look at your parts list and know what items you need to order. that information can be found on this website just by entering your computers serial number or model number.

post_full: Hi, I have had my HP 17 since May 2020, and after 11 months of use, the left hinge started coming loose, cracking the plastic around it. I have not been able to close it or travel with it since April of this year (it is now almost August) because it cracks more, knocking the plastic out of place. I have had to hold it together with electrical tape, but now the right side is starting to feel loose too. I have never dropped my laptop, gotten it wet, left it in any extreme temperature, nothing. I take great care of my electronic devices. I had a Dell Inspiron for 11 years that actually still is usable and intact (albeit slow now), but this HP laptop has such thin plastic that it broke after less than a year of use. A quick online search shows that I'm not remotely the first person to have this issue with HP. What can I do to fix this and is HP doing anything to make these computers better quality? --Tierra

I am now over a week without repair for a care pack service that I paid hundreds of dollars for. if you are reading this and thinking about purchasing an HP laptop - RUN.  (additionally, the "HP employees" that reply to these threads state that they will be private messaging with help and guess what - NO MESSAGES ARE RECEIVED AT ANY POINT).

post_full:
The right hinge on my HP Envy x360, which is just over a year old (was purchased in December 2017) is broken. Around it, the screen is seperating from the back panel. I'm honestly surprised that a laptop from a popular company is already having hardware issues at just one year old, though after looking through the forums it seems like a common problem with the Envy series. Local repair shops are asking for anywhere from $250 to $500 and HP wants $400 for a repair. This seems extremely expensive for a problem thats more of nuisance than something serious that needs immediate attention. Any ideas where I can get a cheaper repair or perhaps repair it myself? $400 is ridiculous when it's their own design flaw. I have never mishandled this laptop. It has never fallen, been submerged in water, or sustained any other sort of hardware damage. And apparently, I cannot get an extended warranty because the original warranty has expired and I cannot purchase a Care Package because "my laptop is not in good condition." Any help would be appreciated. Thank you!

post_full:
I am beyond angry at this point of owning an HP laptop. This is my second Envy Laptop in four years past. The first laptop experienced a broken left hinge and the entire screen came apart, exposing the inside. The Geek squad argued with me about this issue and insulted me by insisting I mishandled or dropped the unit, which was totally not true. They gave me a ridiculous price to attempt to have the unit fixed and suggested trashing it and buying a new unit which I did. That was January 17, 2019. Two weeks ago the NEW computer, another Envy HP Laptop had the very same issue occur. The left hinge literally cracked exposing my left screen side. I am furious, disappointed, and very angry that HP has not corrected this issue to protect us as consumers of their product.  I can not afford another $1500, especially at this stressful and difficult time that most of us are experiencing.   I need help and some sympathy and support from HP.  I have attempted to call and even send EMail to no avail. Please, read my post and offer some sort of remedy in helping me get my computer back to use. 

	MSJJ48

post_full: I received a response dated July 11- I  had posted months ago about my laptop screen falling apart.  I got a stock response from Omar-E who said he was going to refer my problem to someone. Now I got an e-mail saying there was a response, but I searched the link they sent me and I see NO response.So- my laptop was in for a fix in the first few months i  dropped it. They supposedly fixed the crack by replaing the entire case.  When it was returned the screws came out and the top started separating. There were little black dots that were supposed to cover the screws, bit one fell off and there was no screw under the little cover. Guess the repair person was too busy to put the screw back. So I had to return it again, and this time they said there was a part that had to be ordered, and it took weeks to get the laptop back. Then a few months later, everytime I lifted the laptop you could hear something rolling around inside. I called and reported this and got a claim number.  Then one day it stopped rolling around and so I thought whatever was loose just got hung up on something inside and would stay there. So, I cancelled the claim. i also did not want to give my laptop up for a liong time again. Then the clicking started. Everytime you would open the laptop it would make a cracking noise. Then the screen started separating on the corners and then at the actual hinge. If laptops can be made that snap apart, they should beable to make one that stays together. I was always afraid to open my laptop. I felt like I was doing something wrong, but you have to move the screen to open the laptop.This would be made worse by being told that $250 will fix the problem.  I asked the rep if HP had addressed this obvious problem, because I  would not pay for a repair for the same quality that i have now since it will obviously not last for over a year, and then I can pay for the repair again??? Excuse ME!My former HP laptop separated. It was larger and had a thicker and stronger case, but the hinge on one side still separated. That one was not ever dropped. so what is up with the laptops coming apart???? I posted that I fixed mine with Sugru. I got it from Target.  I would like to believe that HP is somehow concerned about my problem, but despite this stock answer online - I have not had any response from a real person. But, the email that I did receive asked me post Kudos for the response that i never received. What a joke

post_full: I didn't really notice this problem until a few months after having this computer. I have been making bi-weekly payments on this wonderful laptop since fall of last year through a local Circuit World. I soon started to notice that even if I opened the laptop slowly or gently, there was this awful cracking noise coming from the computer. I had gotten used to it and assumed it was a minor thing, as I have experienced with other laptops in the past. It wasn't until I had run my hand over the left corner of the laptop that I noticed that the bottom cover had been starting to "pop out" or at least not connect itself correctly to the top cover as the right side did.  I have never once damaged this laptop via tossing, dropping or rough handling. This computer is very expensive and takes a lot from my budget, so I have made sure to take the most absolute delicate care of this computer, including handling and virus protection. Unfortunately, with this computer now being excessively harder to open than it should, and the damage that I'm afraid this left hinge is causing, it has become more than just a "little" problem to me, and I fear that it will only worsen over time. I've noticed that in another forum, a customer had their HP ENVY replaced, but I'm wary that I cannot recieve the same treatment because of my purchase throught Circuit World. I will talk to the employees at Circuit World about getting it fixed or getting a replacement if that applies to me, but for now I'm looking to see if there is a simple, easy fix to this problem, at least one that could save time or money because the left hinge problem seems relatively easy to fix, I'm just not going to take chances with damages to my own computer. This also seems to be a problem that isn't solely happening to me, but very many other HP ENVY 17 owners. Thank you!

I bought my autistic grandson a laptop in December 2017 as he is into coding. Suddenly he found he couldn't open or close the top without the frame around the screen on the left side from separating from the main top.  I was going to see about getting it fixed, but that wasn't going to happen. People who are autistic have lots of problems dealing with sudden problems. I've found that the hinges on HP laptops are defective and that if HP fix it, that will cost a lot. If I could afford it I would just buy him a new laptop. But I can't. Right now he has the top open so it is usable. He uses this computer all the time for school work; writing codes in programs; connecting with others online; and it's the way he calms himself. He goes to it as soon as he gets home from school. He uses it when life is stressful. He takes it with him when visiting the home of others. It helps him adjust to new surroundings. Another problem is the anxiety that separating him from the computer in order to send it some place to get it fixed. I wish I had known about this problems, then I wouldn't have bought this. I have had other HP laptops, desktops and printers with no problems at all. I agree with others that HP should fix this problem without charging customers since they have known of this problem for years.



					
						Solved!
					
					Go to Solution.

Have the exact same problem as @Shaun10 except on a 17" HP laptop of my husband's.  Bought on Black Friday 2017 from Best Buy, although it was received about 2 weeks later, so early December.  Now it's just a couple weeks over warranty and the hinge has stripped away from the base.  This is totally ridiculous that this has been a known flaw for many years, yet it is still happening.  Was told that it would cost about $300 to fix "properly", almost as much as what the original laptop costs.
 
This unit has never been dropped and is used by a 66 yo guy who almost never takes it out of the house and takes very good care of it.  This is a very well known design flaw that happens due to no fault of the owner, I feel it should be fixed at no cost, especially so close to the warranty time.  Had I read about this before I purchased, I would never have bought HP.  If anyone can help me get this fixed at no, or very reasonable cost it would go far toward good customer service.  I am not interested in a coupon to buy a new computer because if that's the case I don't want another HP computer.

post_summary: SERIOUS KNOWN DESIGN FLAW with ENVY x360  Unfortunately, a broken hinge on the HP Envy x360 is not an uncommon issue faced by its users (see list of similar posts) and I am no exemption.     W...
post_full: SERIOUS KNOWN DESIGN FLAW with ENVY x360Unfortunately, a broken hinge on the HP Envy x360 is not an uncommon issue faced by its users (see list of similar posts) and I am no exemption. When closing the laptop (as it is intended) from 90°s the screen pops and detaches from its casing. The hinge appears to have separated internally due to a design flaw present in the laptop model.The laptop has been used delicately throughout and when used like a tablet - seemingly a design advantage, the product failed to meet satisfactory quality. Although out of warranty by less than a year, the Consumer Rights Act 2015 makes it an implied term of the contract I have with HP that goods be as described, fit for purpose, and of satisfactory quality. When contacting customer services to explain that the issue faced, I am met with a quote of over £300 for repair with the best discount of 15%. It is simply unfair to demand repair costs in any sum due to a design flaw faced by many users. Various posts have suggested that HP looked to a remuneration scheme or recall, however, I was unable to confirm this. Similar posts regarding the same design flaw: The most prominent post is: https://h30434.www3.hp.com/t5/Notebook-Hardware-and-Upgrade-Questions/Broken-Hinge-on-Envy-x360/m-p/...  Others:https://h30434.www3.hp.com/t5/Notebook-Hardware-and-Upgrade-Questions/HP-Envy-x360-screen-popped-out...https://h30434.www3.hp.com/t5/Notebook-Hardware-and-Upgrade-Questions/HP-Envy-X360-Hinge-broken/td-p...https://h30434.www3.hp.com/t5/Notebook-Hardware-and-Upgrade-Questions/HP-Envy-x360-Broken-Hinge/td-p...https://h30434.www3.hp.com/t5/Notebook-Hardware-and-Upgrade-Questions/Broken-hinge-on-HP-Envy-x360/t...https://h30434.www3.hp.com/t5/Notebook-Hardware-and-Upgrade-Questions/HP-Envy-13-hinge-issue/td-p/79...https://h30434.www3.hp.com/t5/Notebook-Hardware-and-Upgrade-Questions/Defective-Left-Hinge-HP-Envy-x...https://h30434.www3.hp.com/t5/Notebook-Hardware-and-Upgrade-Questions/Quality-issues-with-Envy-x360-...https://h30434.www3.hp.com/t5/Notebook-Hardware-and-Upgrade-Questions/Broken-Breaking-hinge-on-HP-EN...https://h30434.www3.hp.com/t5/Notebook-Hardware-and-Upgrade-Questions/Defective-Left-Hinge-HP-Envy-x... Images of the flaw (which appear to be modified to become removed):       With HP Customer services being unable to assist, the best I can hope is to have to escalate to an ombudsman or further. I am extremely disappointed with HP and the laptop itself, I had a 2-in-1 convertible laptop in the past that has served me for over 4 years from a different brand [Content Removed]. I decided to save up my money for a better and newer version (or so I thought). I have taken great care of this laptop, there are no scratches, the screen is without any faults and yet by using it for an intended purpose of a tablet - it falls apart as if I tried to convert a standard laptop into a tablet.

post_summary: ...ame broken hinges, no explanations by HP representatives, and the sudden lack of response from HP, this has been one very exhausting situation. I would really just like to send in my sister's laptop to g...
post_full: Hello, My sister's HP Envy x360 laptop broke from the left hinge 2 weeks after her warranty expired. The same thing happened to my HP Envy x360, with the left hinge breaking off a few weeks post-warranty expiration. My laptop was repaired for free, with my sister's laptop requiring an additional cost. We tried to ask why there was discrepancies in service, but were left with no answers. Regardless, 9 months later we decided to just pay for the repair as it was clear HP wasn't willing to explain the discrepancy or offer alternative solutions. There was an offer of the cost to be reduced up to 35% for the repair, and I had let the HP representative know we would be able to send in the laptop at the end of June, as that's when my sister finished her online school. We were given the deadline of July 2nd, and we reached out on June 27th, June 30th, and July 15th. It is now July 26th, and I really want to send in my sister's laptop as I know it takes a 4-6 weeks and will likely take longer due to Covid, but my sister starts her online school in September and we really need the laptop repaired. It's already been a year, and we obliged by HP's conditions. Since messaging the HP representative as led to no response, I'm hoping that posting this issue will allow another HP representative to reach out to us. With having to deal with a two laptops with the same broken hinges, no explanations by HP representatives, and the sudden lack of response from HP, this has been one very exhausting situation. I would really just like to send in my sister's laptop to get it fixed ASAP. Thank you.

Hello, I reached out to the support community about a year ago, for a broken hinge on the left side of my HP Envy x360. An HP escalation executive reached out to me, and we were able to resolve my issue free of cost once I had sent in pictures of my laptop. I would like to point out, that the laptop was less than 1.5 years old at the time, I had not done anything to it, and my previous 2-3 HP laptops also had broken left hinges. In my previous post, I also mentioned how my sister bought an HP Envy x360, two weeks after I bought mine. Similarly, two weeks after my laptop screen came apart, hers started breaking apart too. Now this was shocking as she keeps her laptop on her desk all day, and doesn't even take it to school as I do mine daily. The fact that her laptop started falling apart at the same timeline as my own, and that previous our previous HP laptops also broke with the left hinge, makes me think this may be a hardware issue on the fault of the company. Now, we have been reaching out to HP since October/November 2019, and have constantly been given unsatisfactory solutions. First, we were told to call HP, which costs a decent amount of money that did not seem plausible for a hardware issue. 6 months later, we reached out again, to which the person we spoke with was a different individual who keep ignoring my questions, and at most offered us a 35% discount without even asking for pictures.  This was highly disappointing as my laptop was repaired for free, AFTER the executive had seen the pictures. Secondly, it was to no fault of our own that the laptops began to fall apart, as mentioned before my sister does not even move her laptop from her desk to her bed, so how did her screen start breaking apart? Thirdly, I would be willing to pay a bit to get it fixed, but it is highly disappointing as we paid over $1000 for the laptop, and within the span of a month gave this company $2500 of our business, and much more over the last 12 years. As well as, my sister is in high school and I am a university student, we cannot afford to pay +$300 for repairs when we spent $1200 on the laptop itself, individually. As for ignoring the question, the individual wouldn't answer why mine was repaired for free, why I couldn't speak to the executive as before, and why he wasn't even asking to see the condition of the laptop. He had also mentioned that my sister's laptop was out of warranty and thus cannot be repaired for free. But when we first reached out it had only been out of warranty for 3 months, and mine was also out of warranty, yet it was still repaired free of charge. Now it's obviously been much longer, but only because we haven't been able to come to an agreeable solution. I am upset and disappointed with HP for the lack of clear communication and understanding, I am open to any suggestions on how to repair this laptop with low cost, or any other ways I can reach out to HP and speak with as escalation executive as I hope they will be more understanding. Any suggestions are appreciated and welcome. Thank you.

I have an HP ENVY x360 with a broken left hinge. I have had my laptop for LESS than 2 years, and the broken hinge has progressively gotten worse with pieces of the hardware breaking off and I am also now unable to close my laptop at all.  At first I thought it was something I may have done, as my previous HP laptop had also broken from the left hinge (however I was still able to use it for 6 years through multiple repairs, but it was also only a fraction of the price of an HP ENVY x360). However, my sister bought her HP ENVY x360 on the exact same as I did. Her left hinge began to loosen a week after mine did. She keeps her HP ENVY x360 on her desk at all times.  With both our left hinges breaking, and my previous HP laptop left hinge breaking, I'm beginning to think it's a manufacturing issue. I have no idea what I should do to fix it, where I can take it, and I am beyond upset if I have to pay a tremendous amount (which I could use for a cheaper laptop that'll last me longer) to fix this issue, when this laptop itself already cost more than $1200.  As a university student working minimum wage, I cannot afford to pay high amounts to fix this laptop. Does anyone have any recommendations on what I should do or where I can take it? I'm at a total loss.  P.s. I'd like to get my laptop fixed before the beginning of September as I need it to take notes in class and do my assignments. Much appreciation for anyone that can help! Thank you!

post_summary: I live in France and ordered a HP Envy mid of May.   The hinges started to have problem around July, only 2 months later. I didn't contact the customer service immediately because I needed my c...
post_full:
I live in France and ordered a HP Envy mid of May. The hinges started to have problem around July, only 2 months later. I didn't contact the customer service immediately because I needed my computer everyday (I'm unemployed, job searching and passing interviews several times a week). A few days ago, in August, it became more and more difficult to close the laptop: the cracking noises of the hinges made me fear that the cover or the screen would crack too.  And when I close it fully, the screen reopen a little bit. I contacted the customers service, but was told that this is not covered by the warranty: it would cost me 350€, 30% of the price I paid for the computer only 4 months ago ! I always considered HP as a solid and reliable brand (my close uncle was even an employee), and felt betrayed and shocked to be in this situation where I should pay so much (especially while being unemployed) for something that is under the responsability of the company (I'm not asking for a favor for something that I would have broke by myself). Looking at this forum and over the Internet, it seems like a common problem with HP computers.I would expect HP to either:- fix my hinges (in a way that the issue doesn't come back in 2 months)- replace the computer (in case this one had a specific stronger default on the hinges) to avoid the problem to reappear every 3 months. I believe that under a 1 year warranty, hinge should be covered, otherwise it's raising doubt on the quality of the hinge if the brand expect it to break before a year ? Thank you



					
						Solved!
					
					Go to Solution.

I have tried the phone but there is no  options  for warranty or fault hardware issues and it just hangs up on you??

post_full: I am so upset with HP right now I could scream. I have bought many hp computers and laptops through the years. I have had the same exact issue with my last three laptops and now my newest one. The first two were old and lasted a very long time before it happened so I was okay with purchasing a new one but these last two lasted only 13 months, right outside their warranty and I can’t afford to keep doing this. I believe you are selling faulty product. All four laptops have broken/or come apart at the right side hinge. When I bought the 3rd one I did not buy the hardware warranty because your products have been so dependable and lasted a long time. Shame on me it only lasted 14 months and could not be repaired so in January 2018 I had to buy another one. Spent over $1500.00 at Best Buy, with virus protection and geek squad service. I even asked the salesman if this could possibly happen again and he told me “no ma’am, they have correct that issue with the new ones” so again I did not buy the hardware warranty. Now, I am one month out of warranty and this one has done it again. This is so not fair and I cannot afford another one. My husband is dying of lung cancer and I try to work from home to take care of him. Can you please help me??? It is an HP Envy Sharon Delaney

post_full: I noticed earlier this week that the left hinge on my HP ENVY x360 was broken when I went to close the lid and felt a bit of resistance. When I went to check I noticed that I felt a bit of an unnatural bulge near the area of the display near the left hinge and that the display was slowly coming off near the left side. Thankfully I noticed this problem before I fully closed the lid because I'm afraid that if I go to close the lid fully, my display screen/monitor will get shattered.  It's hard to notice but in this picture, the display is slowly coming off the lid. At 1st after noticing this problem, I decided to go and get a hinge replacement. But, after doing research, I saw that most hinge replacements cost approximately $300. I am a student and I need this computer to do almost all my assignments and I can't spend $300 dollars on fixing this laptop.  Also, I believe this to be a design flaw because I had seen multiple different posts where people had a similar issue to mine  also in regards to a HP ENVY x360. https://h30434.www3.hp.com/t5/Notebook-Hardware-and-Upgrade-Questions/Broken-Hinge-on-Envy-x360/m-p/...https://h30434.www3.hp.com/t5/Notebook-Hardware-and-Upgrade-Questions/Broken-Hinge-on-Envy-x360-Conv...https://h30434.www3.hp.com/t5/Notebook-Hardware-and-Upgrade-Questions/Defective-Left-Hinge-HP-Envy-x...https://h30434.www3.hp.com/t5/Notebook-Hardware-and-Upgrade-Questions/Broken-Breaking-hinge-on-HP-EN...https://h30434.www3.hp.com/t5/Notebook-Hardware-and-Upgrade-Questions/Quality-issues-with-Envy-x360-...I hope that with this post HP could either repair my laptop  or point me towards a place that could without it being too costly and difficult.

post_full:
Purchased HP laptop (HP-ENVY-15-k163cl) from Costco USA 2.5 years ago for around USD 800+. The right hinge broke with in an year and recently the left hinge also broke. This product has 1 year manufacturer warranty plus 2 more years of warranty from costco. This model number is custom built for costco and not available outside costco.I am outside USA (currently in India). The HP service centre here says that the warranty on this product is not valid in India since this specific model is not released in India. They can't even fix it at our cost. The spare part (hinge) is not available in market. This means basically no fix for this problem although it appears to be a manufacturing defect (based on similar issues expressed by other customers.My suggestion to customer is that do not by HP laptop especially from Costco (or similar venders who have custom model build)I still have 8 year old Acer which has no such issue. I am surprised that reputed company like HP is selling defective products (even hig end models) like this!Can HP provide any help regarding this issue?

post_summary: The right side screen hinge on my duaghters laptop has 'exploded' away from the lid of this laptop - this happened when she was opening the lid to use it - not exactly a strenuous 'use case'. Of c...
post_full: The right side screen hinge on my duaghters laptop has 'exploded' away from the lid of this laptop - this happened when she was opening the lid to use it - not exactly a strenuous 'use case'. Of course the warranty expired in August, regardless i have read that people are being charged for a fix even if thier computers are in warranty. A mounting mechanism of this type (3x 2mm screws into brittle plastic) for a laptop that is designed to have its screen folded over into tablet mode is completely unacceptable. It will very likely become a problem for ALL HP laptop owners of this design, i am sure there are many 1000's of them. Time to do some proper engineering so that this doesnt happen any more HP. What is your answer to those who are not willing to pay the 100's of dollars for the repair of a latent defect caused by poor design that occurs during use of the product in the manner it was advertised and sold to be used ?

post_summary: ...ange Envy & pavillion laptops. They are always in the £1300 to £1500 region. The current one has lasted less than 2 years. The internal plastic has become embrittled and the screws which hold the hinge...
post_full: This is not a question, just feedback to other HP customers. I am a Chartered Engineer. I NEED good quality equipment for my work. Over the last 10-12 years I have bought several of the top of the range Envy & pavillion laptops. They are always in the £1300 to £1500 region. The current one has lasted less than 2 years. The internal plastic has become embrittled and the screws which hold the hinges internally no longer have the plastic matrix with the brass bushes to screw into. Now whenever the laptop is open or closed, the internal hinges pop the cover off. Also, the screen has gone, all I can see are lots of horizontal multi-coloured lines. I now can only use it if I plug another monitor and keyboard into it.I wrote to HP last week. Their complaints dept phoned me today. It is out of warranty, they can repair it but I would have to pay, and yes, the repair would be carried out using the same plastic components which become heat embrittled after 12-18 months. The person who rang agreed with me that this was a very common complaint and that I was right to expect more than 2 years from a top end laptop.I said it would cost more than the laptop is currently worth to strip out the internals to replace the plastic carcassing. I asked why they wasted my time by ringing me. They said they just wanted to be polite.I have told them I will never buy HP anything again. I'll buy a new microsoft Surface Pro 7 next month.VERY DISAPPOINTED WITH HP.Save yourselves the hassle, don't pay the top prices for sub-standard equipment. Buy Microsoft or (and I hate to say this!) Apple.

post_summary: ...bsp; I would open it during commercials, then close it during the shows .  After about an hour, I went to open it and heard a massive CRACKKK ! The right hinge had broken free and literally came t...
post_full: Well, after doing a quick search, it seems like I am one of thousands of people that have experienced this massive structural failure of the HP x360 hinge system.  And like many of the accounts I have read, HP tried to blame their hinge design flaw on the buyers. I was sitting watching TV with the laptop on my "lap" which is exactly how it it supposed to be used, hence the name.  I would open it during commercials, then close it during the shows .  After about an hour, I went to open it and heard a massive CRACKKK ! The right hinge had broken free and literally came through the front screen.  Glass shattered off of the hinge and the screen was now only held on by the left hinge.  Upon examination, the 2-3 screws that are supposed to hold the hinge in place had somehow come out and had fallen out in my lap. Since there is no way for a user to access these screws, clearly it is a design flaw or quality control issue which should be addressed by HP. Spent 3.5 hours being given the America to India phone support shuffle being transferred back and forth and finally to a number that was a sales pitch for a medical alert bracelet.  Then here. My laptop is of course just a few months out of warranty,   But as I explained, if I am driving my car that is a few months out of warranty, and the steering wheel comes off in my hand, I will still expect the car company to address this clear design flaw or quality control issue.  From what I have read, this is a VERY common problem certainly not disclosed to me when I purchased the item.  Any solutions out there?

As time goes by it is steadily getting worse and worse and more plastic is breaking and falling out of the screen, I am now afraid to even adjust the tilt of the screen.  EDIT: since it wont show my uploaded pics here is an imgur album;https://imgur.com/a/2XOUrA5 I have never had this happen to any other laptop I have ever owned, and the fact that it started happening two months out of warranty is ridiculous. post_summary: Was wondering if anyone out there can help....last week when attempting to open my laptop the right side hinge appears to be broken/frozen and is locking up. This is forcing the screen display b...
post_full: Was wondering if anyone out there can help....last week when attempting to open my laptop the right side hinge appears to be broken/frozen and is locking up. This is forcing the screen display bezel and the hinge cover  to separate from the touchscreen (http://h10032.www1.hp.com/ctg/Manual/c06941101.pdf page 19). As long as I don't attempt to open or close the screen the computer will continue to operate. If I do close and attempt to re-open the screen without supporting the bezel its going to crack the touch screen and then I'm going to have bigger problems than just replacing the screen hinges.  My questions are as follows:I've looked online in several online vendor stores to try and locate the exact hinge required to mend this problem but haven't had too much success. Several vendors list hinges for HP 15 inch laptops (with vague specs) but most of the vendors I questioned responded that their hinges would not work on a touch screen. Anyone out there know if the part  number listed on page 20 for hinges L52009-001 can be bought anywhere online other than at a local HP store? Also, I'm overseas in Germany using a US Model in a foreign country so locating parts during COVID is not an easy task. I will however be stateside next week so if anyone is aware of a HP outlet or store in the northern VA or southern Maryland district I'm open to suggestions?I've also looked at several options on YouTube for replacing HP hinges on touch screen on similar 15 inch PC's but my particular model is not available on YouTube. If anyone has completed this task before ..and and all advice is welcome. I think I can do this but obviously have some concerns over completely disassembling the screen and keyboard portion of the laptop ---- allot can go wrong!  Help....

post_full: I have a HP Chrome book.  It has developed a crack on the top plastic body near the hinges on both the sides.  It has neither fallen down nor hit by any hard surface. It is still under warranty. But the Hp service persons say it cannot be covered under warranty telling the following reasons.  they do not have past history for such damages.  (I have sent  link of the blog where many such incidents have been discussed) still they are not ready to accept/convince.they say it is not a functional failure but is due to unintentional damage.  I do not understand the difference between these two.they say if there is a mechanical failure in the hinge, it shall come out with out damaging the body. But for me it is very clearly developing pressure on the body when I am opening the tab, and the crack is getting opened up further.  Though the flange has not come out, it is getting opened very tightly.  I have sent the respective photographs to them. Still they are not interested to rectify the issue.

post_full: I bought a HP Pavilion laptop for my son about 2 years ago.  It has always stayed on his desk, stationery, plugged into a monitor and has never been dropped.   Last night, he closed the lid and said he heard a cracking sound, but he didn't think anything of it.  This morning he showed me that when he tried to open the laptop lid, the hinge was completely broken.  It looks like since the hinge was broken and he didn't know it was broken, attempting to open it caused damage to the screen.   I have read a number of other posts about HP laptop owners having defective hinges.  Has anyone been able to get a remedy from HP?  It's out of warranty, but I'm really disappointed that 2 year old laptop has a defective part that makes it unusable.  Any recommendations on how I can get in touch with HP (other than posting here)? Thanks, Philip PS Here are photos.

post_full: Hello.  I'm having an issue when opening my laptop.  Every time I lift the screen to open my laptop, there is resistance on the rights side of the laptop hinge that is starting to separate the screen from the casing.  This is the second laptop I have purchased with the same exact issue.  I ended up having to discard my last laptop since no one from HP was able to help me with this well known issue.  I replaced it with a new one, which was costly, but now it is starting to happen all over again.  Aside from this issue the laptop has been great.  This has become a frustrating issue since I depend on my laptop and I really don't have time to send it out to get fixed.  Can you please propose a solution??? Not sure if I am still under warranty.  In addition to this laptop, I have been a loyal HP customer and have purchased 3 other HP laptops  and a network printer for my family in the past 2 years.  I'd appreciate a fair resolution to this.

Dear Sir/MaamM Hinge of my laptop was broken in October 2018 for which I contact the hp team as the laptop was in warranty. They then sent an engineer after a month to check the issue who handled the laptop very badly. He took off a few things and places them back taking pictures but in the whole process he broke the screen. I told him the thing immediately and he assured me that it will be done in warranty. He then left and they kept me waiting for 4 months and suddenly last month they reject my case stating that hi he breakdown is not covered under warranty but no one is now paying attention to the screen the engineer broke himself. I even contacted your team through WhatsApp but they will simply ignore the screen part and reply with hinge is not covered in warranty. Okay, I will get the hinge repaired all by myself but what about the screen your engineer broke. I am not able to use the laptop from past 4 months . I have been talking to so many people but not getting any positive response. Please help me with this case, I already suffered a lot because of this.

post_full: I searched on Google and found that many people faced similar problem as I am right now. I am using a HP Envy 13 laptop, bought in March 2020. I've been taking great care of this laptop since then as it was my second laptop since high school and my uni life relies heavy on it. I was closing the lid and the bottom of the laptop cracked open. I tried to open the lid back up and then, the hinge popped out. When I approached HP support, they quoted me a service fee of about RM3.5K (approx. 3/4 of the initial price of the laptop) and proceeded to include a so-called "Goodwill" discount, reducing the price to RM2.3K. They also claimed that since my warranty had expired, it is advisable for me to go for this paid service, also saying that it is consumer's mishandling of device. In addition to this, they said that as my laptop is bought in another country, my device is not under global warranty.  Apparently, this hinge issue has been troubling many HP consumers since years ago. There are also claims that this is a manufacturer's problem where HP did not look into this hinge inadequacy and still continued to manufacture laptops with the same hinge. Anyone in the same predicament as mine or has any advice to how should I proceed from here?

Now, each time I close the laptop, I hear more cracking, and more plastic bits fall out of the case. The plastic surrounding the screen is warped drastically, and the metal hinge is exposed.  The screen and the screen case on the left side are no longer attached to the metal hinge. The problem seems to worsen each day, and I'm trying not to close or open the laptop but sometimes that's not an option. I have never dropped the laptop, and have consistently close it carefully since the hinge issues began. Given so many people have experienced the same type of issues, I'm confident HP can provide a viable fix. Thank you in advance.

My computer was purchased about a year ago. Only recently I have been unable to close and open my laptop.  The trim around my screen was pulled off by half of my left plastic hinge, the bottom half. The hinge is in great condition and will even clip back on, but the issue is internally. I don't know how to fix this. I am unable to open or close the lid for because of the broken connection on the left side, my plastic bottom hinge will not move, thus tearing my trim off the lid when I try to open or close.

post_full: Hi my laptop Is somewhat broken. Only the screen itself is affected. Basically the bottom left connection between the computer and screen of my hp envy laptop. Has broken. This caused the screen itself to fracture and then the screen itself has gone dark. I had a personal warranty on the device purchased via amazon. But I forgot I had the warranty back when it broke. Then remembered after the amazon warranty had expired, which came with the laptop. I did however buy it specifically from a branch in the U.K.Where I live and the entirety of the transaction has taken place. Under EU law consumers are offered a two year guarantee in which sellers must repair or replace faulty or not-fit for purpose items, in addition this is trumped by the six year warranty in the UK legislation. The right applies to any goods sold in the UK. So online retailers must also comply. Under these I am covered to the best of my knowledge. i recognise the argument it may be categorised as user induced damage but as both myself and https://h30434.www3.hp.com/t5/user/viewprofilepage/user-id/3381319 have noticed. After doing some research within these forums, it appears that this is a very common issue with these laptops and them all having faulty hinges that give out. Left hinge popped and cracked the bottom left side of my screen. I am in need of repairs on my laptop. post_full:
We now have the exact same issue... Just out of warranty, screen is starting to separate from the case due to a broken hinge. We noticed it and have stopped opening the lid in an effort to prevent the screen from cracking. How is it every single HP Envy owner out there is having this problem and HP isn't owning up to the issue. Sounds like a lawsuit in the making. We've been loyal HP customers for a very very long time, but from what I'm reading here regarding how HP is ignoring this issue we may go a different route for our next purchase. It's sad really because they could own up to it, fix it for their customers, and come out better in the end because not only would they have fixed laptops, but they would create loyalty. 
 
Anyway, could someone from HP please let me know what our options are? Can we ship it in for repair, and if so what are the costs and turnaround times for doing so?
 
Thanks,
Mark

post_full: Hello, can please someone official from HP help me. 6 days ago, after i was done working on my laptop i turned off the laptop and started to close the lid of the laptop, and i heard a crackling sound on the right hinge. I opened the laptop again and I saw that my right hinge is damaged and also the frame of the screen, where the hinge is, is peeled of.  I didn't turn on the laptop i closed it again carefully and went to the nearest authorized HP service, to see it fix as fast as possible and so that no other damage comes to the laptop. I went to the service with my warranty. I brought the laptop to the service, showed to the worker what is the problem without turning the laptop on, after that they told me that they will contact me and I left. They then sent me a mail with a picture  of a new damage on the laptop, that my LCD screen is damaged, which i saw for first time on that picture. They told me that they will fix the hinge for free because it was not properly installed, but not the LCD screen, which I don't understand because the screen was not damaged before. I think the hinge that was not properly installed did the damage to the LCD when it broke, so why should they not fix that damage too, as I said it was not cause by my. I am mad and disappointed at the service, because I have that laptop for maybe just a year and I really took care of it, but they are not willing to fix the problem that the hinge caused, which they admitted it was not properly installed. That is why I am writing here, so that you can help me and tell me if this is possible to fix under the warranty as it should be. Thank you very much. the damaged LCD

post_full: I have an Envy 13. Yes it was from 2019 but it was still expensive enough that known faults should have been repaired. In late 2020, it had a new top cover as (like almost every Envy from that time period) under extended warranty. Now again the screen is flapping around like it is going to detach at any minute. My understanding is that this is not the hinges themselves but rather the fact that they are screwed into plastic, and I also have been told that this is no longer the case (which kind of proves that this is a known issue, aside from the various class actions underway and the fact that I have now been through two). I've read some people have had some help from HP with this issue but they aren't helping me. I have had an outlandish, profiteering repair cost (given that this is due to substandard manufacture, I'd tolerate it more if I had eg dropped it or broken the screen etc!). I would think I should still be entitled to at least the part given that the original two provided were defective? I've tried raising this with HP privately but having 'escalated' this, the case was closed without response (usually a decent indicator that you are right) today. Does anyone have any experiences of this (if they can get them in before this is no doubt removed for discussing a genuine issue!)?

post_full: Purchased this HP laptop at Sam's Club Nov. 2017, Model # 15-bs087cl. I believe they still sell it. The unit is fantastic and I have enjoyed it's size, speed and overall structure, except for one issue....the left hinge. For several months it seemed loose and I just assumed it shifted but was not a problem. One day I went to close the laptop and noticed the display edges separating from  the back  and beginning to bend in a way that would permanently damage it. I began noticing the forum issues and went back to my paperwork to see the warranty info. It had a 1-year mfr warranty and the 2-Year Care Pack was included to extend the warranty. Because it is now April 2020, I need to get this repaired or the unit will further deteriorate. I purchased with a credit card that also offers extension of warranty, but I feel this is an HP issue, and not one of abuse or any mistreatment; I'm on my 10th laptop over the years and this one gets little movement away from a carpeted storage spot. What should I do?

(And different brand!) I gave up on HP printers years ago, but I really have enjoyed my Envy up to this point.

post_full:
I am incredibly disappointed with HP; I purchased my computer just long enough for the warranty to expire before one of the hinges attching the screen to the keyboard snapped, something that has since made the computer difficult to close and, in general, to use. This is a problem that other users have had on other ENVY models, yet when I attempted to reach out to an HP representative via telephone, I was informed that I would be charged $229.99 for a repair. It is both disheartening and mind-boggling that a mechanical issue, very likely one that stems from me being sent a defective product since this was not the result of the computer ever being dropped, would cost me about 20% of the price of the computer to repair.

post_full: Hi, I've noticed for a while that the hinges on my notebook have been becoming progressively weaker and the screen has started to be a lot looser when sat at my desk, moving when typing. I could hear a rattle inside the casing, and on removing the back cover, found that the plastic housing for the gold nuts which hold the hinge screws have completely disintegrated. The plastic is tiny and very flimsy. I paid a pretty good amount for this laptop, so am quite annoyed. I treat my laptop with a lot of care and it sits on a desk, so this really should not happen.Has anyone else found this problem with HP laptops?What can/will HP do to help on this? This really shouldn't be something that I have to pay for to get repaired - the build quality looks to be abysmal despite the otherwsie high spec at time of purchase.Thanks.

post_full: I purchased a Notebook 17in May 2018 from Costco . About May or June 2019 I opened my laptop and the right hinge made a noise and i notice the black and grey plastic were separating. I returned to Costco and was informed of the 90 day policy. HP seems to not know or care that broken hinges are a "thing" with their Laptops. Costco is willing to look at it,but there is a 2-5 days delivery to them 1-3 day repair and 2-5 days for return. I appreciate them, but that is a week( best case scenario) without my computer. My question is: Why does Costco seem more concerned with their brand name than HP? Why is there no "recall?" What is Hp's plan for not letting consumers feel like they wasted $700? How does HP plan to regain the trust of it's customers? Thank you for listening and I welcome your timely response and solution."

post_summary: So my computer has the broken HP hinge issue that is common to HP laptops documented in this forum and all over the internet, just Google this and the Southern District of Florida. I have talked to H...
post_full: So my computer has the broken HP hinge issue that is common to HP laptops documented in this forum and all over the internet, just Google this and the Southern District of Florida. I have talked to HP people on their Facebook page, their support phone number, and this forum and have been quoted anywhere between free and $400 to fix a known design defect in HP's hinge. When I finally got an HP rep to respond here, the first rep offered to fix the hinge for free, we got the information setup to have a box shipped out and all of a sudden a new rep starts talking to me and the first rep goes completely silent. The second rep proceeds to tell me I will have to pay to get the hinge fixed. When I told the second rep the first rep had already agreed to fix it for free and I had the conversation documented, they agreed to fix it for free. Then, the second rep told me they may not be able to fix it due to the common corporate scapegoat "supply chain issues" and offered me a $125 voucher to buy another HP computer. We again, got everything setup for me to send the computer in for HP to attempt to fix the hinge but just like the first rep, the second goes completely silent. So let's see if this gets any attention from HP. For anyone else who comes across this trying to get their hinge fixed, good luck, you will need it.

post_full: Purchased an HP Envy x360 15in laptop at the end of 2020 and just over a year later the hinge on the left side of the screen made a loud popping sound and broke. The screen is starting to detach from the back of the display as well. I contacted HP on Facebook and they said my computer was out of warranty but they told me I could contact the support number and they would be able to help. I called the support number they provided and after a round of call center hot potato with about 5 different people I was told that my computer is out of warranty and I could purchase an extended warranty. I told the phone rep I doubted me buying an extended warranty now would help since I had already reported the broken hinge. The rep finally acknowledged I was right. They then said I could send it off for repair and asked me for my email address and street address. After I gave them that information, they said they couldn't tell me how much it was going to cost and transferred me to another person. I had to tell them all the same information again and they finally told me it would cost over $400 to fix the hinge on a "premium" computer I paid $400 for. This is a know issue with all of HP's x360 line, a quick Google search truns up numerous YouTube videos about this, including a video from HP showing how to replace broken hinges, and a massive list of complaints on this forum about the hinge issue. Even if I would pay to have HP fix the hinges, they will just break in another year. HP's support has been completely unhelpful and un professional, one of the phone reps continuously told me it was all my fault the hinge broke and this isn't a problem with HP computers. Even after I told the rep I didn't drop the computer and there is no other scuffs or dents they continued to insist I intentionally broke the computer. I know I will never by another convertable computer from HP ever again and I'm very unlikely to ever purchase anything from HP ever again over this. HP knows this is an issue and they don't care to address it. HP makes big claims about caring about the environment, if they actually cared about the environment, they would do a better job of designign and building their products so we don't have to constantly buy replacements or ship them off to be repaird, all using fossile fuels and all contributing to increased waste and hurting the environment.

post_summary: ...ndicated the CPU fan is not working and the laptop would shutdown.  I think this issue is related to the hinge problem -- it appears that some of the debris from the broken hinge may have gotten into t...
post_full: I bought my daughter an HP-15-bs131nr laptop for use at college in Dec 2017.  In February 2019 the left hinge of her laptop broke (no damage had been done to the laptop previously -- no drops/rough usage, etc).  She worked around the problem by being very careful when opening the latop since she needed if for school.  In April 2019, she received the 90B error on bootup that indicated the CPU fan is not working and the laptop would shutdown.  I think this issue is related to the hinge problem -- it appears that some of the debris from the broken hinge may have gotten into the CPU fan and jammed it.  I know that the laptop is no longer under warranty, but I know that HP has suffered a large number of hinge failures on their laptops and I hope that HP will provide some answers or assistance with getting her laptop returned to an operating condition.   I tried to contact customer support - but quite frankly the website is rather clunky and I have been unable to get a phone number to contact support.  I received an email from HP saying that I was assigned a case number when I put in my contact information, but I have never received any contact from HP.  Any assistance would be greatly appreciated. Thanks

post_full: I bought an HP ENVY laptop 16 months ago. But since I bought it, I was having issues with the audio system. I sent it for repair twice but still, they couldn't fix it. After the second attempt, I got tired and stopped sending for the so-called "repair". I was adjusting to that issue until this week. But this week, it got broken without doing anything. Since my warranty was expired in Sept (1 yr), I called HP support and requested them for repair. I said many times that I will pay the cost needed to repair it but they said they are unable to fix this specific model. I then visited a local repair center, they said the hinge and screen are broken, which will cost ~$400 to fix. I am now throwing it in the trash and thinking to buy a new brand. post_full: I purchased the HP envy x360 laptop (model as in title description) online and the UK PC world Currys chain was the seller. However within the 30 day period the left hinge broke. Then I tried to rotate it back and the hinge came out of the screen. I thought it wouldnt be difficult to snap it back into place but after attempting to do that the second right hinge came out. And repeated attempts to fix this resulted in a cracked screen and the Currys seller refused to compensate claiming damage was induced by me and couldnt apply prompt repair within the 30 day period of purchase as accidental damage is not covered. While this is true the initial problem was with the hinge itself, and there are repeated posts about a flaw in the design of the left hinge specifically which seems to have been the root cause of this. Understandably I am not too pleased with the situation , I am seeking advice on what steps to take it any are available to resolve this issue? Right now I dont see a way forward and just accepting that this sets me back ~600 pounds. I would only be okay if I applied excessive force or sudden jerking motion but my laptop was not subjected to anything that should cause a hinge to come out.

post_full: Hello HP Community, Would advise you to notify your friends and family NOT to go for the new Elitebook series . Nightmare began in march 1st week, within two months of purchase of the laptop worth 1.5 Lacs INR . The display screen got unhinged on its own without any pressure , damaging the screen . With red and blue lines on the screen the laptop was left unusable. Thousands of calls requests to HP authorised center ( dont even try the whatsapp or other conversations - these calls will not resolve any issue but exist only to give the impression that the complaint and the user are being taken care of) led to a technician being assigned by TVS E -authorised service center in Mumbai on 7th March 2019. Post that it has been living hell trying to get HP to replace the part which is out of warranty. TVS E has no idea when the part will be delivered and HP call center has zero accountability in trying to close the loop. [edit]

post_full: Hi HP Community, Purchased the HP Elitebook X360 in  Jan 2019 as official and personal usage. Though it has a touchscreen tablet mode, i have scarcely used this mode. Mostly used the standard laptop format. Despite minimal usage and wear tear, the right hand hinge started shaking and the display screen got unseated from its base, rendering the screen with purple lines and a black shade covering 30% of the screen area. This model with the config that i have taken costs upwards of 150 K INR.Any one who has recently purchased faced this poor workmanship on a highly rated HP Laptop  ?Its been just 60 days of limited usage and already the hinges are wobbly and the screen has come out of its case. HP service center is yet to depute an engineer for the same. Disappointed with you, HP !

post_summary: ...aptop to hear a loud snap. I checked my laptop and saw that one of the hinges came loose as well as some of the cover of the laptop on top. I wasn’t sure how this could’ve happened. I’ve never dropped my c...
post_full: So, I purchased this laptop in January of 2018 to replace another HP laptop that a family member had accidentally broken. The laptop worked just fine, but just this week, I had closed my laptop to hear a loud snap. I checked my laptop and saw that one of the hinges came loose as well as some of the cover of the laptop on top. I wasn’t sure how this could’ve happened. I’ve never dropped my computer, and I don’t take it anywhere. The most I’ve done to this computer is opening and closing it. And unfortunately, my warranty had expired just a month ago. I was willing to repair my laptop, and I took it to a repair store who told me I need to replace the entire LCD back cover of my laptop. The part I needed wasn’t available, however. Not on the HP parts store, not on Ebay, and not on Amazon. The part number is 926489-001. I’m not entirely sure what to do, as I would rather not buy a new laptop, which would be pricey, and all my information is stored on this laptop, but I need a new computer immediately for college. I’ve been using HP for the past 7 years, and I considered it the only brand I trust, and I’m deeply disappointed at this, my laptop broke all on its own. Is there a way I could contact HP and possibly resolve this issue? I’m not entirely sure what to do. Thank you!

So I bought my hp envy x360 barely a year ago, and have hardly used it since buying it for graphic design and not really having time to do that.. here I am a month over my warranty expiring, I picked up the laptop to move it from my desk to my room and noticed the screen separating because of a broken hinge.. from what I’m seeing HP knows this is an issue, and does not like to fix it even with a current warranty for some.. not really sure what to do, but I guess HP will not be a brand we continue using if I cannot get into contact with someone to help me at barely a year of owning a $1000 pc that’s already broken from less than normal wear and tear…

post_full: Hello HP, I've had my envy for around 4 years and the problem of the left hinge started a long time ago. In fact, when I first showed this computer to my colleague he mentioned that at some point the left hinge was going to break at some point in the near future. I then noticed a pop sound every time I would open/close the laptop but I ignored it until the casing started to pop. I then realized that it was starting to look similar to what my colleague reported when he started this thread:  https://h30434.www3.hp.com/t5/Notebook-Hardware-and-Upgrade-Questions/17-quot-HP-Envy-Coming-apart-a... Our institution had recommended these laptops but so far two of us who are using them have had the same problem and we really love the performance but the left hinges seem to be problematic as per the posts below:  https://h30434.www3.hp.com/t5/Notebook-Hardware-and-Upgrade-Questions/17-quot-HP-Envy-Coming-apart-a... https://h30434.www3.hp.com/t5/Notebook-Hardware-and-Upgrade-Questions/HP-Envy-17-quot-Left-HInge-Bro...https://h30434.www3.hp.com/t5/Notebook-Hardware-and-Upgrade-Questions/HP-Envy-15-6-quot-Left-Hinge-B...https://h30434.www3.hp.com/t5/Notebook-Hardware-and-Upgrade-Questions/17-quot-HP-Envy-Coming-apart-a... Also note that I rarely use this computer - You can see from the casing that it has no scratches or dents from regular use or any sort of abuse. I only started using it regularly recently after switching from my other computer and this is when the hinge problem was aggravated.  Please advise on how to resolve this - everyone I have spoken to informs that this is a design issue from HP and I should be entitled to support.  Thanks and regards, Sara

post_summary: Hello, I purchased an HP Spectre 360 a little over a year ago. Within 2 days I experienced what appeared to be a stress crack near the hinge. Luckily I purchased a Geek Squad protection warranty a...
post_full: Hello, I purchased an HP Spectre 360 a little over a year ago. Within 2 days I experienced what appeared to be a stress crack near the hinge. Luckily I purchased a Geek Squad protection warranty and was able to get the screen repaired. However, I noticed that there would be times that my notebook would experience flickers that would impact my mouse sensitivity and at times cause screen flickers. Usually closing my notebook and reopening it would temporally resolve the problem. However, I recently experienced another spontaneous screen crack that AGAIN appeared to originate at the hinge. The notebook was sitting on my desk charging overnight. When I opened the notebook to check my email I noticed the crack. AGAIN, I took my notebook BACK to Best Buy to have it repaired for a second time. I LITERALLY just received the notebook back YESTERDAY afternoon, TODAY I am experiencing the screen flickers and mouse interruption ALL over again. (Keep in mind I have a BRAND NEW screen) AGAIN it appears that the stress may be related to the hinge. I decided to research the issue because what are the odds that the same symptoms and ultimately need for repair would present multiple times? While researching it appears that this is a common issue with the HP Spectre 360. What is HP doing to address these issues to prevent them from recurring? I suspect that this may be a design flaw if so how is HP addressing this issue?  Has anyone else experienced this issue?  If so, how was it resolved once and for all?

I put tape around the corner for support, which worked for a few months, but now the other hinge has also snapped. This has caused the casing to start separating from that side as well. I now have a laptop with two broken hinges, casing that is falling apart, and a crack on one of the front bottom corners. I cannot afford to replace this laptop or spend a lot of money getting it repaired, and will be needing it for a distance learning course in 2016. I am disappointed at how fragile this laptop seems to be, as I was looking forward to many more years with it, and I don't think it will last much longer in its current condition. This puts me in a difficult situation as I use this laptop regularly, and rely on it being in good working order. I no longer feel I can open and close this laptop without causing significant damage, and am at a loss for where to go from here. Is there anything that can be done?Thank you.

 Sybil [Thank you for visiting the HP Support Forums. I am sorry to inform you that your post has needed some editing to remove personal information.]

post_full:
Hi all, I have multiple HP laptops but I guess I am learning that their hinges are really bad. This is my second HP x360 that landed with a broken hinge and just this time it also caused the screen to crack. I called up the repair (it is under warranty) and they asked me to send it in. After keeping the laptop for six days and telling me that the laptop has been repaired and under testing, I got a message today that this is customer induced damage. No further information is shared. I need help in dealing with the situation. I have photos of the laptop before I sent it. Clearly the screen broke at the hinge point and that too it came out. I don't think HP wants to tell me that I somehow pulled out the screen. Also other than this, I do not have a single scratch on the laptop. I know this forum is to solve other operating issues but I am hoping someone with similar experience may be able to help on how to get HP to honor their warrenty.

post_full: We bought our HP Envy x360 laptop in late 2018 from Costco in preparation to replace our older computer. I thought that the HP-Costco-Citi relayed 4-year warranty would well cover us. I was even happier when we started using it in Feb. 2019 and saw that HP online record showed the one-year manufacture's warranty was from Feb. 2019 to Feb.2020. Not long after the one-year manufacturer's warranty expired in Feb. 2020, the hinge issue came up. The laptop still has Year2 to Year4 warranty covered by Costco and Citi card benefits but we could not get a requested repair quote right away because of factors such as its being used every day, the stay-at-home orders, etc. When we finally were able to go to the HP certified repair center available within 50 miles, UBreakIfix, they could only provide a non-repair statement because the top case needed was unavailable indefinitely. In searching for repair options, I found that this was in fact a pretty common design flaw in many envy laptops as https://h30434.www3.hp.com/t5/Notebook-Hardware-and-Upgrade-Questions/HP-Envy-X360-Hinge-broken/m-p/...Begin Quotes 1. https://h30434.www3.hp.com/t5/Notebook-Video-Display-and-Touch/HP-Envy-Left-Hinge-Broken/m-p/6979085...2. https://h30434.www3.hp.com/t5/Notebook-Hardware-and-Upgrade-Questions/HP-Envy-Hinge-Popped-Open/m-p/...3. https://h30434.www3.hp.com/t5/Notebook-Hardware-and-Upgrade-Questions/HP-ENVY-x360-15T-BP000-HINGE-I...4. https://h30434.www3.hp.com/t5/Notebook-Hardware-and-Upgrade-Questions/Defective-Left-Hinge-HP-Envy-x...5. https://h30434.www3.hp.com/t5/Notebook-Hardware-and-Upgrade-Questions/Defective-left-hinge-HP-ENVY-x... End-QuotesBecause of this experience, we returned two HP laptops recently purchased from Costco. I hope someone seeing this post can help us find a feasible repair solution.

I purchased this laptop for approximately $1,000 expecting it to last a few years, not break once the warranty expires. Most likely will not be returning to HP moving forward.

I noticed the left hinge began to break, so I kept it open 24/7 from that point out but still had to close it occassionally when it was on the go with me. Now at this point the corner near the power putting is coming up and there's a crack near the left ESC button and the hinge is still broken. I would hate for my laptop to give out on me seeing as this is my first one and I'm a student and I use this for everything. I love the laptop, but it's unfair on how much money is put into these laptops and in return after a year or so the laptop wants to begin to fall apart. Please help. Thank you in advance!

I paid a lot for this laptop and now I am left with a damaged bottom. Makes me feel like I bought a lemon from HP. I am very"]
post_full: #1Long story short, I bought HP Envy 17T (17M-AE111DX) laptop earlier this year that has HUGE problem with the hinge, and IMO a clear design defect.The hinge is really stiff, which is understandable given the size of the screen (17.3"). The problem is that the super stuff hinge and it's metal assembly is mounted simply onto the 2~3mm thick ABS plastic bottom case without any bracing or support. So as you open and close your LCD trhough daily use, you are putting tremendous stress on the screw mount points on that ABS plastic bottom case lid.It took about 8 month of use but it finally busted the screw mount point for the right side (as you use the laptop) hinge. There are only 7 screws holding the bottom cover together, and only 2 of them are used for securing the hinge to the bottom cover. This is the most incompetent design I've seen for a laptop hinge.  I called HP support and they asked me which side the hinge was broken. Then they told me they don't do any warranty repair on broken covers. If they don't do warranty repairs on broken covers, then why did they asked me which side broke first? They told me it will cost me $380 to fix it. I said the cover probably costs $50 from HP site. They basically said because the cover was physically broken, the warranty is void. Anyone else have this kind of issue with the 17" Envy laptops?

post_full: I posted for help in the HP Community Support as an inside hinge has apparently broken in my laptop and it is causing the display to pop out. I was responded to by a "rep" who provided generic information as to how to go about getting it repaired at my cost to the tune of $250. WHY should we have to pay for a repair that we didn't cause?  I saw that he had more engagement with others that are having the same issue so I sent a direct message and he asked for my laptop info in order to have it looked into. And since then, I have heard nothing. This is not acceptable. This is clearly a design flaw as there are thousands of people reporting this issue. I cannot imagine that HP doesn't think this is something that they should take care of. I have included the contents of my original post below and I truly hope that you will help to resolve this issue. If I must pay anything, it will be for a new NON HP product. HP Pavilion x360 - Screen Popping Out & Loose Hinges‎09-19-2021 06:01 PMProduct: Pavilion X360Operating System: Microsoft Windows 10 (64-Bit)My laptop is just 3 years old and yesterday when opening, I heard a clicking sound. Every time I opened/closed the lid or adjusted it, I heard it and it is wobbly. I looked at it today and the screen is popping out in the lower right hand corner. I can see everything behind it! And it seems the hinge(s) are loose and they are no longer even on both sides. This seems quite ridiculous and must be a design flaw as the laptop has not been dropped or had anything dropped on it. How does this just suddenly happen? On top of that, this model is the one that can be folded to convert to a tablet and I have only ever even done that twice since the purchase. Please help! I am a student and cannot afford to purchase another new laptop after only a couple of years due to again what can only be described as a design flaw.

I think that may be the cause of the issue. I can't find the drivers anywhere. It worked for about 15 minutes a week ago and reflected the HP Wide Vision HD Camera driver version 10.0.18362.693, which was up to date. I rebooted and attempted to use the camera the following day, and the driver was gone. I have tried recovering from an external hard drive, doing a Reset and reinstalling Windows 10, and nothing is working.  Please help me get my webcam back.

So, this is a story. I was using my laptop downstairs when I closed the lid (closed perfectly fine, as it had thousands of times) as I had the intention of moving it upstairs. Once upstairs, I attempted to open the lid of the laptop with a sudden cracking noise and extreme resistance when opening the device. I managed to get it open, and I noticed that the bottom right bezel where the HP logo is printed had separation between the plastic and the screen. Glue was visible, and it was extremely hard to open/close the lid because of the plastic wedging between the gap in the screen and the bottom half of the laptop. This literally happened so suddenly, it went from closing perfectly fine to this. I've had this machine for about 2 - 3 years, never had any hardware issues (I did do a SSD swap). Never dropped, screen is not cracked, I used this laptop as my daily driver for school. Is there a way to fix this? *Edit: Forgot to mention the machine is not closable without absolutely ripping out the bezel of the screen.* I attached a video where you can see the issues I am describing.

post_full: I purchased my x360 envy 9 months ago (I have had to send it off for repair twice already in that time because of a WiFi connection problem!) Whilst using the laptop I opened the screen and heard a crack, only to see that the left hinge had dropped and smashed through the bottom corner of the screen! The hinge was completely stuck making it difficult to even close the laptop for transporting it. I phoned the warranty company and was told to take it to my closest Currys for them to send it off, where the technician also told me, it was a manufacturing problem. So, what am I supposed to do when they sent me back my product unrepaird as it isn't covered by my service agreement?! This is clearly not an isolated incident and one simple Google search shows that it is infact a massive manufacturing problem with these laptops, so any help as to what my next steps should be would be greatly appreciated. I'd just like to stress, I didn't at any point drop or damage the laptop and I'm sure we can all agree that being expected to buy a new laptop after months is just insanity!

post_full:
I am the owner of an HP ENVY Laptop 13 --Product Number: 8MX92AVTo give you context, it has never been dropped and nothing's every been spilled on it.  This laptop does not leave my office--literally.  It came apart all on it's own! Last week, the rear hinge on my laptop separated so that every time I opened it, the right hinge stuck out.  So in order to close it, I had to manually adjust the hinge to properly close it.  It thereby made a distinct "clicking" sound each time I opened or closed the laptop.  I also noticed the lower right corner where the screen is mounted began to separate as it was becoming unglued.  All of these problems originated on the right side of the laptop.   Within 48 hours, opening it gently, my screen detached from the frame and split!  I am at a total loss as to what to do.  I'm currently using my backup 17.3 HP G72 which is well over a decade old and has never given me a single issue.  I purchased this laptop in September 2020 and it is now worthless.  Please help HP!  I'm a loyal customer and I love my computer.
